IND_WAL.name: Wall Ratio
IND_WAL.definition: IND_WAL assesses the vertical enclosure of a space by determining the proportion of the visual field occupied by walls, building facades, or solid barriers. This indicator helps quantify the 'canyon effect' in urban planning and influences the psychological feeling of confinement or security. By measuring the ratio of vertical solid surfaces, researchers can evaluate the relationship between built edges and the pedestrian scale, which directly impacts the visual complexity and perceived density of an architectural environment.

variables.Pixel_Wall: Number of pixels classified as wall/fence
variables.Total_Pixels: Total number of pixels in the image

IND_FNC.name: Fence Ratio
IND_FNC.definition: IND_FNC quantifies the visual prominence of boundary markers, specifically focusing on fences, railings, and gates. It is calculated as the proportion of the view plane covered by these dividing structures. This indicator is significant in environmental psychology and crime prevention through environmental design (CPTED) as it relates to territoriality, privacy, and visual permeability. A high fence ratio may indicate a defensive spatial character, affecting social interaction and the aesthetic continuity between private properties and the public realm.

supporting_papers.citation: Zhang, Y., Li, S., Dong, R., Deng, H., Fu, X., Wang, C., Yu, T., Jia, T., & Zhao, J. (2021). Quantifying physical and psychological perceptions of urban scenes using deep learning. Land Use Policy, 111, 105762.

variables.Pixels_Total: Total number of pixels in the image

IND_FRD.name: Fractal Dimension
IND_FRD.definition: IND_FRD is a quantitative measure of morphological complexity and roughness, derived from fractal geometry. In visual landscape analysis, it assesses the texture and edge complexity of skylines or vegetation patterns, typically using the box-counting method. A higher fractal dimension suggests a more complex, information-rich visual environment, often resembling natural forms. This indicator is widely used in environmental psychology to predict preference, as humans tend to prefer mid-to-high fractal complexity which mimics the structural order found in nature.

variables.N(r): Number of boxes covering the pattern

supporting_papers.citation: Kawshalya, L. W. G., Weerasinghe, U. G. D., & Chandrasekara, D. P. (2022). The impact of visual complexity on perceived safety and comfort of the users: A study on urban streetscape of Sri Lanka. PLOS ONE, 17(8), e0272074.

IND_SIM.name: Similarity
IND_SIM.definition: IND_SIM quantifies the uniformity and repetition of visual elements within a given environment. It assesses the extent to which textures, colors, forms, or architectural styles are replicated across a scene. While high similarity contributes to a sense of order and harmony, excessive similarity can lead to monotony. In urban design analysis, this indicator helps evaluate the balance between chaotic diversity and cohesive identity, ensuring that a streetscape possesses enough unifying traits to be aesthetically pleasing without becoming tedious.

variables.n: Number of pixels in category i

supporting_papers.citation: Amiruzzaman, M., Zhao, Y., Amiruzzaman, S., Karpinski, A. C., & Wu, T. H. (2023). An AI-based framework for studying visual diversity of urban neighborhoods and its relationship with socio-demographic variables. Journal of Computational Social Science, 6(1), 315–337.

IND_SHA.name: Shade Coverage
IND_SHA.definition: IND_SHA calculates the proportion of a specific area or visual frame that is protected from direct solar radiation by obstructions such as trees, buildings, or canopies. This indicator is a vital component of thermal comfort modelling and microclimate analysis. By quantifying the extent of shadowed surfaces, planners can assess the usability of outdoor spaces during hot periods. It links the physical configuration of urban geometry and vegetation canopy to the physiological well-being and cooling experience of pedestrians.

supporting_papers.citation: Zeng, L., Lindberg, F., Zhang, X., Pan, H., & Lu, J. (2023). Road surface temperature evaluated with streetview-derived parameters in a hot and humid megacity. Urban Climate, 51, 101585.

variables.n: Total number of annuli in the divided fisheye image
variables.i: Index of the specific annulus (from 1 to n)
variables.p_i: Number of pixels of the specific element (sky, greenery, or building) in annulus i
variables.t_i: Total number of pixels in annulus i

IND_SFI.first_confirmed_by: Rui, Q., & Cheng, H. (2023). Quantifying the spatial quality of urban streets with open street view images: A case study of the main urban area of Fuzhou. Ecological Indicators, 156, 111204.

IND_GVI_ANG.name: Green View Index by Vertical Angle

supporting_papers.citation: Sakamoto, S., Kogure, M., Hanibuchi, T., Nakaya, N., Hozawa, A., & Nakaya, T. (2023). Effects of greenery at different heights in neighbourhood streetscapes on leisure walking: A cross-sectional study using machine learning of streetscape images in Sendai City, Japan. International Journal of Health Geographics, 22(1).

IND_GVI_ANG.definition: The proportion of vegetation pixels within specific vertical angular ranges (latitudes) of a fisheye-projected sky map, centered on the viewer's zenith.
IND_GVI_ANG.formula: Ratio of vegetation pixels in latitudinal zone / Total pixels in latitudinal zone
IND_GVI_ANG.first_confirmed_by: Sakamoto, S., Kogure, M., Hanibuchi, T. et al. Effects of greenery at different heights in neighbourhood streetscapes on leisure walking: a cross-sectional study using machine learning of streetscape images in Sendai City, Japan. Int J Health Geogr 22, 29 (2023).

IND_RID_RAT.name: Rider Ratio

supporting_papers.citation: Shao, Y., Yin, Y., Xue, Z., & Ma, D. (2023). Assessing and Comparing the Visual Comfort of Streets across Four Chinese Megacities Using AI-Based Image Analysis and the Perceptive Evaluation Method. Land, 12(4), 834.

IND_RID_RAT.definition: The proportion of pixels in a street view image representing riders (persons on vehicles such as bicycles or motorcycles).

variables.Pixels_Rider: Number of pixels classified as Rider
variables.Total_Pixels: Total number of pixels in the image

IND_RID_RAT.first_confirmed_by: Shao, Y., Yin, Y., Xue, Z., & Ma, D. (2023). Assessing and Comparing the Visual Comfort of Streets across Four Chinese Megacities Using AI-Based Image Analysis and the Perceptive Evaluation Method. Land, 12(4), 834.

IND_WLK_SCR.name: Walkability Score (Tao et al.)

supporting_papers.citation: Tao, Y., Wang, Y., Wang, X., Tian, G., & Zhang, S. (2022). Measuring the Correlation between Human Activity Density and Streetscape Perceptions: An Analysis Based on Baidu Street View Images in Zhengzhou, China. Land, 11(3), 400.

IND_WLK_SCR.definition: A visual perception score for walkability, defined as the ratio of pedestrian elements (sidewalk, fence) to vehicle road elements.
IND_WLK_SCR.first_confirmed_by: Tao, Y.; Wang, Y.; Wang, X.; Tian, G.; Zhang, S. Measuring the Correlation between Human Activity Density and Streetscape Perceptions: An Analysis Based on Baidu Street View Images in Zhengzhou, China. Land 2022, 11, 400.

IND_HPS.name: Human Perception Score

supporting_papers.citation: Tao, Y., Wang, Y., Wang, X., Tian, G., & Zhang, S. (2022). Measuring the Correlation between Human Activity Density and Streetscape Perceptions: An Analysis Based on Baidu Street View Images in Zhengzhou, China. Land, 11(3), 400.

IND_HPS.definition: A composite score derived from Greenness, Openness, Enclosure, Walkability, and Imageability using Entropy Weighting Method.
IND_HPS.formula: Weighted Sum(Greenness, Openness, Enclosure, Walkability, Imageability)
IND_HPS.first_confirmed_by: Tao, Y.; Wang, Y.; Wang, X.; Tian, G.; Zhang, S. Measuring the Correlation between Human Activity Density and Streetscape Perceptions: An Analysis Based on Baidu Street View Images in Zhengzhou, China. Land 2022, 11, 400.

IND_VSD.name: Vegetation Structural Diversity

supporting_papers.citation: Tong, M., She, J., Tan, J., Li, M., Ge, R., & Gao, Y. (2020). Evaluating Street Greenery by Multiple Indicators Using Street-Level Imagery and Satellite Images: A Case Study in Nanjing, China. Forests, 11(12), 1347.

IND_VSD.definition: A measure of the diversity of vegetation vertical layers (trees, shrubs, herbs) calculated using the Shannon-Wiener index based on semantic segmentation pixel counts.

variables.pi: Proportion of specific vegetation type pixels relative to total vegetation pixels

IND_VSD.first_confirmed_by: Tong, M., She, J., Tan, J., Li, M., Ge, R., & Gao, Y. (2020). Evaluating Street Greenery by Multiple Indicators Using Street-Level Imagery and Satellite Images: A Case Study in Nanjing, China. Forests, 11(12), 1347.

IND_VIS_QUA.name: Visual Quality Index
IND_VIS_QUA.definition: A composite index of visual environmental quality derived from multiple perceptual dimensions (e.g., safety, beauty, wealth).
IND_VIS_QUA.formula: Sum(Safety, Liveliness, Beauty, Wealth, Cheerfulness, Interestingness)
IND_VIS_QUA.first_confirmed_by: Wang, Z., Ito, K., & Biljecki, F. (2024). Assessing the equity and evolution of urban visual perceptual quality with time series street view imagery. Cities, 145, 104704.

IND_TVW.name: Type of Visual Walkability

supporting_papers.citation: Wang, M., Haworth, J., Chen, H., Liu, Y., & Shi, Z. (2024). Investigating the potential of crowdsourced street-level imagery in understanding the spatiotemporal dynamics of cities: A case study of walkability in Inner London. Cities, 153, 105243.

IND_TVW.definition: A categorical classification of street segments based on the clustering of visual walkability indicators (greenery, openness, pavement, crowdedness).
IND_TVW.first_confirmed_by: Wang, M., Haworth, J., Chen, H., Liu, Y., & Shi, Z. (2024). Investigating the potential of crowdsourced street-level imagery in understanding the spatiotemporal dynamics of cities: A case study of walkability in Inner London. Cities, 153, 105243.

IND_VPI.name: Visual Pavement Index

supporting_papers.citation: Wang, M., Haworth, J., Chen, H., Liu, Y., & Shi, Z. (2024). Investigating the potential of crowdsourced street-level imagery in understanding the spatiotemporal dynamics of cities: A case study of walkability in Inner London. Cities, 153, 105243.

IND_VPI.definition: The ratio of visible pavement pixels to the sum of pavement and road pixels, indicating the dominance of pedestrian space relative to vehicle space.
IND_VPI.first_confirmed_by: Wang, M., Haworth, J., Chen, H., Liu, Y., & Shi, Z. (2024). Investigating the potential of crowdsourced street-level imagery in understanding the spatiotemporal dynamics of cities: A case study of walkability in Inner London. Cities, 153, 105243.

IND_WLK_RAT.name: Visual Walkability Ratio

supporting_papers.citation: Ye, Y., Zeng, W., Shen, Q., Zhang, X., & Lu, Y. (2019). The visual quality of streets: A human-centred continuous measurement based on machine learning algorithms and street view images. Environment and Planning B: Urban Analytics and City Science, 46(8), 1439–1457.

IND_WLK_RAT.definition: The ratio of pedestrian-oriented pixels (pavement, fence) to road pixels in a street view image.
IND_WLK_RAT.first_confirmed_by: Dai, L., Zheng, C., Dong, Z., Yao, Y., Wang, R., Zhang, X., ... & Guan, Q. (2021). Analyzing the correlation between visual space and residents’ psychology in Wuhan, China using street-view images and deep-learning technique. City and Environment Interactions, 11, 100069.

IND_TRF_VIS.name: Visual Traffic Flow Index

supporting_papers.citation: Dai, L., Zheng, C., Dong, Z., Yao, Y., Wang, R., Zhang, X., Ren, S., Zhang, J., Song, X., & Guan, Q. (2021). Analyzing the correlation between visual space and residents' psychology in Wuhan, China using street-view images and deep-learning technique. City and Environment Interactions, 11, 100069.

IND_TRF_VIS.definition: The proportion of the visual field occupied by dynamic traffic elements (cars and pedestrians).
IND_TRF_VIS.first_confirmed_by: Dai, L., Zheng, C., Dong, Z., Yao, Y., Wang, R., Zhang, X., ... & Guan, Q. (2021). Analyzing the correlation between visual space and residents’ psychology in Wuhan, China using street-view images and deep-learning technique. City and Environment Interactions, 11, 100069.

IND_VSG_BLK.name: Visible Street Greenery (Block Level)
IND_VSG_BLK.definition: The average proportion of vegetation pixels in street view images surrounding a block, aggregated using a distance decay model.
IND_VSG_BLK.formula: Gn = Σ(Gi * Li * Di^α) / Σ(Li * Di^α)

variables.Gn: Visible greenery value of each block
variables.Gi: Visible greenery values of surrounding streets

IND_VSG_BLK.first_confirmed_by: Ye, Y., Xie, H., Fang, J., Jiang, H., & Wang, D. (2019). Daily Accessed Street Greenery and Housing Price: Measuring Economic Performance of Human-Scale Streetscapes via New Urban Data. Sustainability, 11(6), 1741.

IND_DIR_RAT.name: Dirt Ratio

supporting_papers.citation: Zhang, Y., Li, S., Dong, R., Deng, H., Fu, X., Wang, C., Yu, T., Jia, T., & Zhao, J. (2021). Quantifying physical and psychological perceptions of urban scenes using deep learning. Land Use Policy, 111, 105762.

IND_DIR_RAT.definition: The proportion of the visual field occupied by dirt or bare ground.

variables.Pixels_Dirt: Count of pixels identified as dirt

IND_DIR_RAT.first_confirmed_by: Zhang, Y., Li, S., Dong, R., Deng, H., Fu, X., Wang, C., Yu, T., Jia, T., & Zhao, J. (2021). Quantifying physical and psychological perceptions of urban scenes using deep learning. Land Use Policy, 111, 105762.

IND_WLD.name: Wildness

supporting_papers.citation: Zhang, X., Lin, E. S., Tan, P. Y., Qi, J., & Waykool, R. (2023). Assessment of visual landscape quality of urban green spaces using image-based metrics derived from perceived sensory dimensions. Environmental Impact Assessment Review, 102, 107200.

IND_WLD.definition: The inverse tangent of the ratio of flora (bushes/wild nature) to grass and non-natural elements, indicating 'urban wildness' vs generic nature.
IND_WLD.first_confirmed_by: Zhang, X., Lin, E. S., Tan, P. Y., Qi, J., & Waykool, R. (2023). Assessment of visual landscape quality of urban green spaces using image-based metrics derived from perceived sensory dimensions. Environmental Impact Assessment Review, 102, 107200.

IND_SPD.name: Spatial Division

supporting_papers.citation: Zhang, X., Lin, E. S., Tan, P. Y., Qi, J., & Waykool, R. (2023). Assessment of visual landscape quality of urban green spaces using image-based metrics derived from perceived sensory dimensions. Environmental Impact Assessment Review, 102, 107200.

IND_SPD.definition: Sum of the area proportions of elements dividing a coherent and integral space for activity.
IND_SPD.first_confirmed_by: Zhang, X., Lin, E. S., Tan, P. Y., Qi, J., & Waykool, R. (2023). Assessment of visual landscape quality of urban green spaces using image-based metrics derived from perceived sensory dimensions. Environmental Impact Assessment Review, 102, 107200.

IND_GVI_VAR.name: GVI Variation
IND_GVI_VAR.definition: Standard deviation of Green View Index across the four horizontal views, indicating heterogeneity of greenery.
IND_GVI_VAR.first_confirmed_by: Zhang, X., Lin, E. S., Tan, P. Y., Qi, J., & Waykool, R. (2023). Assessment of visual landscape quality of urban green spaces using image-based metrics derived from perceived sensory dimensions. Environmental Impact Assessment Review, 102, 107200.

IND_SEF.name: Service Facility
IND_SEF.definition: Sum of the area proportions of service facilities for use and decoration.
IND_SEF.formula: Sum(bench + streetlight + signboard + rain_canopy + flowerpot + sculpture)
IND_SEF.first_confirmed_by: Zhang, X., Lin, E. S., Tan, P. Y., Qi, J., & Waykool, R. (2023). Assessment of visual landscape quality of urban green spaces using image-based metrics derived from perceived sensory dimensions. Environmental Impact Assessment Review, 102, 107200.

IND_WLK_IDX.name: Walkability Index (Visual)

supporting_papers.citation: Zhu, J., Li, B., Ouyang, H., Wang, Y., & Bai, Z. (2024). Understanding Urban Residents' Walking Exercise Preferences: An Empirical Study Using Street View Images and Trajectory Data. Buildings, 14(2), 549.

IND_WLK_IDX.definition: The ratio of sidewalk pixels to the sum of sidewalk and driveway pixels in a street view image.
IND_WLK_IDX.first_confirmed_by: Zhang, W., Guan, H., Li, S., Huang, B., Hong, W., & Liu, W. (2024). The impact of street-scale built environments on urban park visitations: A case study in Wuhan. Applied Geography, 171, 103374.

IND_SAF_IDX.name: Street Safety Index (Visual)
IND_SAF_IDX.definition: The ratio of pixels representing safety facilities (fences, street lamps, traffic lights, cameras) to total road pixels.

variables.Safety_Facilities_Pixels: Sum of fence, lamp, light, and camera pixels

IND_SAF_IDX.first_confirmed_by: Zhang, W., Guan, H., Li, S., Huang, B., Hong, W., & Liu, W. (2024). The impact of street-scale built environments on urban park visitations: A case study in Wuhan. Applied Geography, 171, 103374.

IND_CPR.name: Compression Ratio
IND_CPR.definition: The ratio of the file size of an image after compression (e.g., JPEG) to its original uncompressed size, used as a proxy for information density.
IND_CPR.first_confirmed_by: Zhao, J.; Suo, W. Research on the Construction and Application of a SVM-Based Quantification Model for Streetscape Visual Complexity. Land 2024, 13, 1953.

IND_GRC_CON.name: Grayscale Contrast (GLCM)
IND_GRC_CON.definition: A texture measure from the Gray Level Co-occurrence Matrix (GLCM) representing the difference in intensity between neighboring pixels.
IND_GRC_CON.first_confirmed_by: Zhao, J.; Suo, W. Research on the Construction and Application of a SVM-Based Quantification Model for Streetscape Visual Complexity. Land 2024, 13, 1953.

IND_WLK_IDX_MA.name: Walkability Index (Ma et al.)

supporting_papers.citation: Zhao, X., Lu, Y., & Lin, G. (2024). An integrated deep learning approach for assessing the visual qualities of built environments utilizing street view images. Engineering Applications of Artificial Intelligence, 130, 107805.

IND_WLK_IDX_MA.definition: A visual walkability index calculated as the ratio of pedestrian facility pixels (sidewalks + fences) to road pixels.
IND_WLK_IDX_MA.first_confirmed_by: Zhao, X., Lu, Y., & Lin, G. (2024). An integrated deep learning approach for assessing the visual qualities of built environments utilizing street view images. Engineering Applications of Artificial Intelligence, 130, 107805.

IND_SQI.name: Street Quality Index (Composite)

supporting_papers.citation: Jin, K., Yang, T., & Guo, W. (2023). Urban Street Quality Measurement Methods Combining Street View Images. 2023 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Information Processing (AIIIP), 29–38.

IND_SQI.definition: A composite index measuring the overall spatial quality of an urban street based on visual indicators including green view, enclosure, motorization, and openness, derived via AHP weights.
IND_SQI.first_confirmed_by: Jin, K., Guo, W., & Yang, T. (2023). Urban Street Quality Measurement Methods Combining Street View Images. 2023 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Information Processing (AIIIP), 29-38.

IND_FAC_ENC.name: Facade Enclosure Type

supporting_papers.citation: Zhu, J., Qiu, L., Su, Y., Guo, Q., Hu, T., Bao, H., Luo, J., Wu, S., Xu, Q., Wang, Z., & Pan, Y. (2022). Disentangling the effects of the surrounding environment on street-side greenery: Evidence from Hangzhou. Ecological Indicators, 143, 109153.

IND_FAC_ENC.definition: Categorical indicator distinguishing between sealed/impervious walls and railing/open facades.
IND_FAC_ENC.first_confirmed_by: Zhu, J., Qiu, L., Su, Y., Guo, Q., Hu, T., Bao, H., ... & Pan, Y. (2022). Disentangling the effects of the surrounding environment on street-side greenery: Evidence from Hangzhou. Ecological Indicators, 143, 109153.

CAT_CMP.definition: Based on element quantity, coverage, proportion

MTH_PWC.definition: MTH_PWC is a comparative evaluation method where items or criteria are compared against each other in pairs to establish a hierarchy or relative weighting. Often associated with the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP), this approach reduces the cognitive complexity of judging many items simultaneously. By focusing on the preference or importance of one element over another in isolation (e.g., 'Is Scene A more pleasant than Scene B?'), this method generates robust, consistent data for ranking landscape qualities or subjective preferences.
MTH_PWC.first_confirmed_by: Zhao, X., & Lin, G. (2024). Research on the Perception Evaluation of Urban Green Spaces Using Panoramic Images and Deep Learning: A Case Study of Zhujiang Park in Guangzhou. Landscape Architecture Frontiers, 12(6), 007-024.

MTH_QST.name: Questionnaire
MTH_QST.definition: MTH_QST is a structured data collection instrument consisting of a series of questions or prompts designed to gather information from respondents. In environmental perception studies, questionnaires typically utilize Likert scales or semantic differentials to capture subjective data regarding preferences, emotional responses, or demographic information. This method allows for the standardized quantification of qualitative human experiences, enabling statistical analysis of how different user groups perceive and value specific environmental attributes or urban design interventions.

supporting_papers.citation: Qiu, Y., Pan, H., Kalantari, Z., Giusti, M., & Che, S. (2023). The natural focus: Combining deep learning and eye-tracking to understand public perceptions of urban ecosystem aesthetics. Ecological Indicators, 156, 111181.

Zheng, Y., Lan, S., Zhao, J., Liu, Y., He, S., & Liu, C. (2024). Modeling the Effect of Greenways' Multilevel Visual Characteristics on Thermal Perception in Summer Based on Bayesian Network and Computer Vision. Land, 13(11), 1796.

MTH_QST.first_confirmed_by: Cheng, H., Li, Z., Gou, F., Wang, Z., & Zhai, W. (2024). Urban green space, perceived everyday discrimination and mental health among rural-to-urban migrants: a multilevel analysis in Wuhan, China. BMC Public Health, 24(1), 2788.

MTH_GIS.name: GIS Analysis

supporting_papers.citation: Huang, C., Hu, T., Duan, Y., Li, Q., Chen, N., Wang, Q., Zhou, M., & Rao, P. (2022). Effect of urban morphology on air pollution distribution in high-density urban blocks based on mobile monitoring and machine learning. Building and Environment, 219, 109173.

Zhang, M., Shen, T., Huo, L., Liao, S., Shen, W., & Li, Y. (2025). Study on Mechanism of Visual Comfort Perception in Urban 3D Landscape. Buildings, 15(4), 628.

MTH_GIS.first_confirmed_by: Amiruzzaman, M., Zhao, Y., Amiruzzaman, S., Karpinski, A. C., & Wu, T. H. (2023). An AI-based framework for studying visual diversity of urban neighborhoods and its relationship with socio-demographic variables. Journal of Computational Social Science, 6, 315–337.

MTH_ISO.name: Isovist Analysis

supporting_papers.citation: Cai, M., Xiang, L., & Ng, E. (2023). How does the visual environment influence pedestrian physiological stress? Evidence from high-density cities using ambulatory technology and spatial machine learning. Sustainable Cities and Society, 96, 104695.

MTH_ISO.definition: A geometrical method for analyzing the visible area from a specific vantage point.
MTH_ISO.first_confirmed_by: Cai, M., Xiang, L., & Ng, E. (2023). How does the visual environment influence pedestrian physiological stress? Evidence from high-density cities using ambulatory technology and spatial machine learning. Sustainable Cities and Society, 96, 104695.

MTH_MAN.name: Manual Interpretation

supporting_papers.citation: Zhu, J., Qiu, L., Su, Y., Guo, Q., Hu, T., Bao, H., Luo, J., Wu, S., Xu, Q., Wang, Z., & Pan, Y. (2022). Disentangling the effects of the surrounding environment on street-side greenery: Evidence from Hangzhou. Ecological Indicators, 143, 109153.

MTH_MAN.definition: Human visual identification and classification of image pixels.
MTH_MAN.first_confirmed_by: Chen, X., Meng, Q., Hu, D., Zhang, L., & Yang, J. (2019). Evaluating Greenery around Streets Using Baidu Panoramic Street View Images and the Panoramic Green View Index. Forests, 10(12), 1109.

MTH_FSH.name: Fisheye Projection Analysis

supporting_papers.citation: Li, X., Ratti, C., & Seiferling, I. (2017). Mapping Urban Landscapes Along Streets Using Google Street View. Lecture Notes in Geoinformation and Cartography, 341–356.

Wang, K., Fang, X., Ma, Y., Xue, S., & Yin, S. (2022). Assessing Effects of Urban Greenery on the Regulation Mechanism of Microclimate and Outdoor Thermal Comfort during Winter in China's Cold Region. Land, 11(9), 1442.

MTH_FSH.definition: A method of processing images to simulate or analyze a 180-degree hemispherical view, often used for calculating view factors.
MTH_FSH.first_confirmed_by: Hua, J., Cai, M., Shi, Y., Ren, C., Xie, J., Chung, L. C. H., ... & Webster, C. (2022). Investigating pedestrian-level greenery in urban forms in a high-density city for urban planning. Sustainable Cities and Society, 80, 103755.

MTH_PHO.name: Photographic Method
MTH_PHO.definition: A method for calculating view factors (like SVF) by projecting a fisheye image onto a hemisphere and integrating the visible angles (Steyn, 1980).
MTH_PHO.first_confirmed_by: Li, X., Santi, P., Courtney, T. K., Verma, S. K., & Ratti, C. (2018). Investigating the association between streetscapes and human walking activities using Google Street View and human trajectory data. Transactions in GIS, 22(4).

MTH_RAY.name: Ray Tracing Analysis

supporting_papers.citation: Wu, R., Fang, X., Brown, R., Liu, S., & Zhao, H. (2023). Establishing a link between complex courtyard spaces and thermal comfort: A major advancement in evidence-based design. Building and Environment, 245, 110852.

MTH_RAY.definition: A computational method simulating light paths to calculate obstruction or visibility, often used with 3D building models to determine Sky View Factors.
MTH_RAY.first_confirmed_by: Li, X., Santi, P., Courtney, T. K., Verma, S. K., & Ratti, C. (2018). Investigating the association between streetscapes and human walking activities using Google Street View and human trajectory data. Transactions in GIS, 22(4).

MTH_SML.name: Simulation Modeling

supporting_papers.citation: Li, X., Ratti, C., & Seiferling, I. (2018). Quantifying the shade provision of street trees in urban landscape: A case study in Boston, USA, using Google Street View. Landscape and Urban Planning, 169, 81–91.
Long, Y., & Ye, Y. (2019). Measuring human-scale urban form and its performance. Landscape and Urban Planning, 191, 103612.

Zhu, H., Nan, X., Yang, F., & Bao, Z. (2023). Utilizing the green view index to improve the urban street greenery index system: A statistical study using road patterns and vegetation structures as entry points. Landscape and Urban Planning, 237, 104780.

MTH_SML.definition: The use of digital 3D models (building footprints, DSM, LiDAR) to computationally simulate environmental parameters (e.g., solar radiation, wind, SVF) without direct physical measurement.
MTH_SML.first_confirmed_by: Li, X., Ratti, C., & Seiferling, I. (2018). Quantifying the shade provision of street trees in urban landscape: A case study in Boston, USA, using Google Street View. Landscape and Urban Planning, 169, 81-91.

MTH_SPA_AUT.name: Spatial Autocorrelation Analysis

supporting_papers.citation: Xue, C., Jin, C., Zhou, L., & Li, G. (2022). Exploring the distribution of city street greenery from eye-level: An application of Baidu Map panoramic images data. Geografisk Tidsskrift-Danish Journal of Geography, 122(1), 73–86.

MTH_SPA_AUT.definition: A method to measure the correlation of a variable with itself through space (e.g., Moran's I).
MTH_SPA_AUT.first_confirmed_by: Long, Y., & Liu, L. (2017). How green are the streets? An analysis for central areas of Chinese cities using Tencent Street View. PLOS ONE, 12(2), e0171110.

MTH_UME.name: Urban Multi-scale Environmental Predictor

supporting_papers.citation: Ni, Y., Lin, L., Xia, H., & Wang, X. (2025). Urban Street Greening and Resident Comfort: An Integrated Approach Based on High-Precision Shadow Distribution and Facade Visual Assessment. Sustainability, 17(3), 1026.

MTH_UME.definition: A climate service tool (UMEP) used to model outdoor thermal comfort, shadow patterns, and solar radiation.
MTH_UME.first_confirmed_by: Ni, Y.; Lin, L.; Xia, H.; Wang, X. Urban Street Greening and Resident Comfort: An Integrated Approach Based on High-Precision Shadow Distribution and Facade Visual Assessment. Sustainability 2025, 17, 1026.

MTH_AHP.name: Analytic Hierarchy Process

supporting_papers.citation: Jin, K., Yang, T., & Guo, W. (2023). Urban Street Quality Measurement Methods Combining Street View Images. 2023 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Intelligent Information Processing (AIIIP), 29–38.

MTH_AHP.definition: A structured technique for organizing and analyzing complex decisions, based on mathematics and psychology, used here for weighting indicators.
MTH_AHP.first_confirmed_by: Ni, Y.; Lin, L.; Xia, H.; Wang, X. Urban Street Greening and Resident Comfort: An Integrated Approach Based on High-Precision Shadow Distribution and Facade Visual Assessment. Sustainability 2025, 17, 1026.

MTH_ORT_PRJ.name: Orthographic Projection Transformation

supporting_papers.citation: Sakamoto, S., Kogure, M., Hanibuchi, T., Nakaya, N., Hozawa, A., & Nakaya, T. (2023). Effects of greenery at different heights in neighbourhood streetscapes on leisure walking: A cross-sectional study using machine learning of streetscape images in Sendai City, Japan. International Journal of Health Geographics, 22(1).

MTH_ORT_PRJ.definition: The transformation of equi-cylindrical panoramic images into an orthographic (fisheye/sky map) projection to analyze elements based on vertical angular position relative to the viewer.
MTH_ORT_PRJ.first_confirmed_by: Sakamoto, S., Kogure, M., Hanibuchi, T. et al. Effects of greenery at different heights in neighbourhood streetscapes on leisure walking: a cross-sectional study using machine learning of streetscape images in Sendai City, Japan. Int J Health Geogr 22, 29 (2023).

MTH_RNG_DIV.name: Vertical Viewing Angle Division

supporting_papers.citation: Tong, Z., & Gong, C. (2022). Integrating Characteristics of Vertical Viewing Angle into Quantitative Analysis of Street View Photos. 2022 29th International Conference on Geoinformatics, 1–6.

MTH_RNG_DIV.definition: The method of dividing a street view image into concentric rings (e.g., 0-30°, 30-50°, 50-90°) to analyze visual elements within specific fields of view.
MTH_RNG_DIV.first_confirmed_by: Tong, Z., & Gong, C. (2022). Integrating Characteristics of Vertical Viewing Angle into Quantitative Analysis of Street View Photos. 2022 29th International Conference on Geoinformatics, 1-6.

MTH_FSH_PRJ.name: Fisheye Projection Transformation

supporting_papers.citation: Zou, J., Jiang, H., Ying, W., & Qiu, B. (2024). Scenic Influences on Walking Preferences in Urban Forest Parks from Top-View and Eye-Level Perspectives. Forests, 15(11), 2020.

MTH_FSH_PRJ.definition: The mathematical transformation of a panoramic (cylindrical) image into an azimuthal (fisheye) projection for view factor calculation.
MTH_FSH_PRJ.first_confirmed_by: Xu, H.; Lu, H.; Liu, S. Online Street View-Based Approach for Sky View Factor Estimation: A Case Study of Nanjing, China. Appl. Sci. 2024, 14, 2133.

MTH_SBE.name: Scenic Beauty Estimation

supporting_papers.citation: Zhu, J., Li, B., Ouyang, H., Wang, Y., & Bai, Z. (2024). Understanding Urban Residents' Walking Exercise Preferences: An Empirical Study Using Street View Images and Trajectory Data. Buildings, 14(2), 549.

MTH_SBE.definition: A psychophysical method developed to assess the visual quality of a landscape through human ratings, often by experts or the public.
MTH_SBE.first_confirmed_by: Zhu, J.; Li, B.; Ouyang, H.; Wang, Y.; Bai, Z. Understanding Urban Residents’ Walking Exercise Preferences: An Empirical Study Using Street View Images and Trajectory Data. Buildings 2024, 14, 549.

MTH_CLS.name: Cluster Analysis
MTH_CLS.definition: A multivariate statistical technique and unsupervised machine learning method used to group a set of objects in such a way that objects in the same group (called a cluster) are more similar to each other—in terms of specific variables or dimensions—than to those in other groups. It is frequently used in urban studies to identify spatial patterns or typologies.

supporting_papers.citation: Torkko, J., Poom, A., Willberg, E., & Toivonen, T. (2023). How to best map greenery from a human perspective? Comparing computational measurements with human perception. Frontiers in Sustainable Cities, 5.

MTH_OIA.name: Object-Based Image Analysis (OBIA)
MTH_OIA.definition: A remote sensing and computer vision method that analyzes digital imagery by partitioning it into meaningful image objects (segments) based on spectral, geometrical, and topological characteristics, rather than analyzing individual pixels. This approach is particularly effective for high-resolution street view or satellite imagery to classify complex urban features.

supporting_papers.citation: Li, X., Zhang, C., & Li, W. (2015). Does the Visibility of Greenery Increase Perceived Safety in Urban Areas? Evidence from the Place Pulse 1.0 Dataset. ISPRS International Journal of Geo-Information, 4(3), 1166–1183.

MTH_TSV.name: Tencent Street View Analysis
MTH_TSV.definition: A methodological approach utilizing the application programming interfaces (APIs) and imagery datasets provided by Tencent Maps. Researchers employ this method to extract large-scale, street-level visual data for analyzing urban built environments, assessing greenery, calculating walkability, and modeling human-scale perceptions of city spaces in China.

supporting_papers.citation: Tong, M., She, J., Tan, J., Li, M., Ge, R., & Gao, Y. (2020). Evaluating Street Greenery by Multiple Indicators Using Street-Level Imagery and Satellite Images: A Case Study in Nanjing, China. Forests, 11(12), 1347.

MTH_HOT.name: Hot Spot Analysis
MTH_HOT.definition: A spatial analysis technique, often utilizing the Getis-Ord Gi* statistic, used to identify statistically significant spatial clusters of high values (hot spots) and low values (cold spots). It goes beyond simple density mapping by determining where features with high or low values cluster spatially in a way that is unlikely to result from random chance.

supporting_papers.paper_file: Song J, Zhu X and Yu X (2023) Monitoring and mapping vegetation greenery in resi
supporting_papers.citation: Song, J., Zhu, X., & Yu, X. (2023). Monitoring and mapping vegetation greenery in residential communities using street view images and a Normalized Vegetation Greenery Index: A case study in Beijing, China. Frontiers in Forests and Global Change, 6.

MTH_CLA.name: Classification Analysis
MTH_CLA.definition: A supervised machine learning or statistical procedure used to categorize data into distinct, predefined classes. In urban research, this is often applied to land-use data, satellite imagery, or survey results to predict categorical outcomes (e.g., residential vs. commercial, high-risk vs. low-risk) based on input feature vectors.

supporting_papers.citation: Liu, W., Hu, X., Song, Z., & Yuan, X. (2023). Identifying the integrated visual characteristics of greenway landscape: A focus on human perception. Sustainable Cities and Society, 99, 104937.

MTH_KMN.name: K-Means Clustering
MTH_KMN.definition: A popular vector quantization and unsupervised learning algorithm that partitions a dataset into 'K' distinct, non-overlapping subgroups (clusters). It operates by iteratively assigning data points to the nearest cluster centroid and minimizing the within-cluster sum of squares. It is widely used for market segmentation and identifying urban functional zones.

supporting_papers.citation: Wang, M., Haworth, J., Chen, H., Liu, Y., & Shi, Z. (2024). Investigating the potential of crowdsourced street-level imagery in understanding the spatiotemporal dynamics of cities: A case study of walkability in Inner London. Cities, 153, 105243.

MTH_PSP.name: Perspective Transformation
MTH_PSP.definition: An image processing technique used to project a 3D scene onto a 2D plane or to correct the geometric distortion in images to change the viewing angle. In street view analysis, this method is crucial for rectifying panoramic images or standardizing the visual perspective to simulate a human's eye-level view for accurate environmental auditing.

supporting_papers.citation: Li, B., Xing, H., Cao, D., Yang, G., & Zhang, H. (2022). Exploring the Effects of Roadside Vegetation on the Urban Thermal Environment Using Street View Images. International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health, 19(3), 1272.

Lu, Y. (2018). The Association of Urban Greenness and Walking Behavior: Using Google Street View and Deep Learning Techniques to Estimate Residents' Exposure to Urban Greenness. International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health, 15(8), 1576.

Meng, Y., Xing, H., Yuan, Y., Wong, M. S., & Fan, K. (2020). Sensing urban poverty: From the perspective of human perception-based greenery and open-space landscapes. Computers, Environment and Urban Systems, 84, 101544.

Qiu, W., Li, W., Liu, X., & Huang, X. (2022). Subjectively Measured Streetscape Qualities for Shanghai with Large-Scale Application of Computer Vision and Machine Learning. Proceedings of the 2021 DigitalFUTURES, 242–251.

Tong, M., She, J., Tan, J., Li, M., Ge, R., & Gao, Y. (2020). Evaluating Street Greenery by Multiple Indicators Using Street-Level Imagery and Satellite Images: A Case Study in Nanjing, China. Forests, 11(12), 1347.

Wu, D., Gong, J., Liang, J., Sun, J., & Zhang, G. (2020). Analyzing the Influence of Urban Street Greening and Street Buildings on Summertime Air Pollution Based on Street View Image Data. ISPRS International Journal of Geo-Information, 9(9), 500.
Yu, C., & Kwan, M.-P. (2024). Dynamic greenspace exposure, individual mental health status and momentary stress level: A study using multiple greenspace measurements. Health & Place, 86, 103213.

Zhang, X., Lin, E. S., Tan, P. Y., Qi, J., & Waykool, R. (2023). Assessment of visual landscape quality of urban green spaces using image-based metrics derived from perceived sensory dimensions. Environmental Impact Assessment Review, 102, 107200.

MTH_PDL.name: Polynomial Distributed Lag
MTH_PDL.definition: A statistical technique used in time-series analysis and econometrics, also known as the Almon lag model. It imposes a polynomial structure on the lag weights to estimate the delayed effect of an independent variable on a dependent variable. Alternatively, in deep learning contexts, this acronym may refer to Pixel-level Deep Learning for image segmentation.

supporting_papers.citation: Qin, X., Yang, D., & Wangari, V. W. (2024). Quantitative characterization and evaluation of highway greening landscape spatial quality based on deep learning. Environmental Impact Assessment Review, 107, 107559.

MTH_CPM.name: Discrete Choice Model
MTH_CPM.definition: A class of statistical models, including Logit and Probit models, used to predict and explain the choices made by decision-makers among a discrete set of alternatives. It is a foundational method in transportation planning and urban economics for modeling travel mode choice, residential location choice, and route selection.

supporting_papers.citation: Kameoka, T., Uchida, A., Sasaki, Y., & Ise, T. (2022). Assessing streetscape greenery with deep neural network using Google Street View. Breeding Science, 72(1), 107–114.

MTH_IMG_HST.name: Image Histogram
MTH_IMG_HST.definition: A graphical representation of the tonal distribution in a digital image. It plots the number of pixels for each tonal value (intensity). In image processing and remote sensing, histogram analysis is a fundamental method used for thresholding, contrast adjustment, and analyzing the overall brightness and contrast of the captured scene to identify features.

supporting_papers.citation: Zang, P., Liu, X., Zhao, Y., Guo, H., Lu, Y., & Xue, C. Q. L. (2020). Eye-Level Street Greenery and Walking Behaviors of Older Adults. International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health, 17(17), 6130.

MTH_SLM.name: Spatial Lag Model
MTH_SLM.definition: A statistical method used in spatial econometrics and remote sensing analysis. The Spatial Lag Model accounts for spatial dependence by including a spatially lagged dependent variable, acknowledging that the value of a variable at one location is influenced by the values of the same variable at neighboring locations. This is crucial for analyzing geospatial data where observations are not independent.

supporting_papers.citation: Wang, R., Feng, Z., Pearce, J., Yao, Y., Li, X., & Liu, Y. (2021). The distribution of greenspace quantity and quality and their association with neighbourhood socioeconomic conditions in Guangzhou, China: A new approach using deep learning method and street view images. Sustainable Cities and Society, 66, 102664.

MTH_GCM.name: Grey-Level Co-occurrence Matrix
MTH_GCM.definition: A statistical method for examining texture that considers the spatial relationship of pixels. The GLCM functions by calculating how often pairs of pixels with specific values and in a specified spatial relationship occur in an image, creating a matrix from which texture features (like contrast, correlation, and homogeneity) are extracted.

MTH_GLC.name: Global Land Cover
MTH_GLC.definition: Refers to classification methodologies used to map the biophysical cover over the Earth's surface. In the context of algorithms, it often refers to standardized classification schemes or specific datasets (like GLC2000) used as a method to categorize image pixels into classes such as forest, agriculture, water, and urban areas.

MTH_MRC.name: Multi-Resolution Classification
MTH_MRC.definition: An image analysis approach that processes data at multiple scales or spatial resolutions. By analyzing features at different levels of detail, this method can capture both fine textures and broad contextual information, significantly improving the accuracy of land cover classification and object recognition in complex remote sensing imagery.

supporting_papers.citation: Qiu, W., Li, W., Liu, X., & Huang, X. (2022). Subjectively Measured Streetscape Qualities for Shanghai with Large-Scale Application of Computer Vision and Machine Learning. Proceedings of the 2021 DigitalFUTURES, 242–251.

MTH_SEG_NET.name: SegNet (Semantic Segmentation Network)
MTH_SEG_NET.definition: A deep convolutional encoder-decoder architecture specifically designed for semantic pixel-wise image segmentation. The core method involves an encoder network to generate feature maps and a corresponding decoder network that upsamples these maps to produce a dense classification output, widely used for understanding scene geometry and content in autonomous systems.

supporting_papers.citation: Lei, Y., Zhou, H., Xue, L., Yuan, L., Liu, Y., Wang, M., & Wang, C. (2024). Evaluating and Comparing Human Perceptions of Streets in Two Megacities by Integrating Street-View Images, Deep Learning, and Space Syntax. Buildings, 14(6), 1847.

Shen, Q., Zeng, W., Ye, Y., Arisona, S. M., Schubiger, S., Burkhard, R., & Qu, H. (2018). StreetVizor: Visual Exploration of Human-Scale Urban Forms Based on Street Views. IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics, 24(1), 1004–1013.
Xiao, Y., Zhang, Y., Sun, Y., Tao, P., & Kuang, X. (2020). Does Green Space Really Matter for Residents' Obesity? A New Perspective From Baidu Street View. Frontiers in Public Health, 8.

Ye, Y., Zeng, W., Shen, Q., Zhang, X., & Lu, Y. (2019). The visual quality of streets: A human-centred continuous measurement based on machine learning algorithms and street view images. Environment and Planning B: Urban Analytics and City Science, 46(8), 1439–1457.
Zhou, H., Tao, G., Yan, X., & Sun, J. (2021). Influences of greening and structures on urban thermal environments: A case study in Xuzhou City, China. Urban Forestry & Urban Greening, 66, 127386.

MTH_VDVI.name: Visible Difference Vegetation Index
MTH_VDVI.definition: A vegetation index designed for processing imagery containing only the visible spectrum (Red, Green, Blue), useful for low-cost UAV sensors lacking a Near-Infrared band. It is calculated as (2*Green - Red - Blue) / (2*Green + Red + Blue) to distinguish green vegetation from soil and other non-plant features.

supporting_papers.citation: Xue, C., Jin, C., Zhou, L., & Li, G. (2022). Exploring the distribution of city street greenery from eye-level: An application of Baidu Map panoramic images data. Geografisk Tidsskrift-Danish Journal of Geography, 122(1), 73–86.

MTH_GSV.name: Google Street View
MTH_GSV.definition: Google Street View is identified as an online street view service that provides an enormous number of images at the street level, functioning as an electronic map based on actual scenery. The text highlights that the emergence of such services has shattered previous restrictions on data availability for evaluating streetscapes. Along with similar services like Tencent Street View, it offers images rich in detail with wide coverage, serving as a vital data source for evaluating the visual perception of urban streets.

supporting_papers.citation: Li, X., Ratti, C., & Seiferling, I. (2017). Mapping Urban Landscapes Along Streets Using Google Street View. Lecture Notes in Geoinformation and Cartography, 341–356.

Li, X., Ratti, C., & Seiferling, I. (2018). Quantifying the shade provision of street trees in urban landscape: A case study in Boston, USA, using Google Street View. Landscape and Urban Planning, 169, 81–91.
Long, Y., & Ye, Y. (2019). Measuring human-scale urban form and its performance. Landscape and Urban Planning, 191, 103612.

Nishio, S., & Ito, F. (2019). Application of Method for Calculating Sky View Factor Using Google Street View: Relation Between Sky View Factor and Physical Elements in Urban Space. Proceedings of the ICA, 2, 1–8.

O'Regan, A. C., Byrne, R., Hellebust, S., & Nyhan, M. M. (2022). Associations between Google Street View-derived urban greenspace metrics and air pollution measured using a distributed sensor network. Sustainable Cities and Society, 87, 104221.
Larkin, A., & Hystad, P. (2019). Evaluating street view exposure measures of visible green space for health research. Journal of Exposure Science & Environmental Epidemiology, 29(4), 447–456.

MTH_GSV.source_paper: Liang Cheng et al. - 2017 - Use of Tencent Street View Imagery for Visual Percep

MTH_JPG.name: Joint Photographic Experts Group (Compression)
MTH_JPG.definition: While commonly known as a file format, in a methodological context, this refers to the lossy compression algorithm defined by the committee. It utilizes the Discrete Cosine Transform (DCT) to reduce image file size by discarding high-frequency information that is less perceptible to the human eye, which impacts the spectral fidelity of images used for analysis.

MTH_SEG_COL.name: Segmentation by Color
MTH_SEG_COL.definition: While not explicitly named 'Segmentation by Color,' the text describes this method in the context of calculating the green view index. It involves analyzing street view images by counting the proportion of specific colored pixels—specifically green-colored pixels—to determine the value of a visual index. This approach allows for the quantitative assessment of landscape elements (such as vegetation) by isolating and measuring image data based on chromatic properties within the photographic samples.

supporting_papers.citation: Cheng, L., Chu, S., Zong, W., Li, S., Wu, J., & Li, M. (2017). Use of Tencent Street View Imagery for Visual Perception of Streets. ISPRS International Journal of Geo-Information, 6(9), 265.

MTH_SEG_COL.source_paper: Liang Cheng et al. - 2017 - Use of Tencent Street View Imagery for Visual Percep

MTH_OCV.name: Open Circuit Voltage
MTH_OCV.definition: A measurement method used primarily in electrochemistry and battery management systems to determine the electric potential difference between two terminals of a device when disconnected from any circuit. In data modeling and non-destructive testing, OCV curves are utilized to estimate the state of charge (SoC) or health of energy storage devices.

supporting_papers.citation: Nishio, S., & Ito, F. (2019). Application of Method for Calculating Sky View Factor Using Google Street View: Relation Between Sky View Factor and Physical Elements in Urban Space. Proceedings of the ICA, 2, 1–8.

MTH_SEG.name: Image Segmentation
MTH_SEG.definition: In the context of this study, image segmentation is described as a specific image processing method within a technical procedure designed to extract characteristics from large quantities of street view images. It is applied to panoramic images that have been processed to be compatible with human visual perspectives. This technique is utilized in conjunction with the detection of salient regions to automate the information acquisition required for determining the visual perception of streets.

supporting_papers.citation: Kang, Y., Zhang, F., Gao, S., Lin, H., & Liu, Y. (2020). A review of urban physical environment sensing using street view imagery in public health studies. Annals of GIS, 26(3), 261–275.

Kawshalya, L. W. G., Weerasinghe, U. G. D., & Chandrasekara, D. P. (2022). The impact of visual complexity on perceived safety and comfort of the users: A study on urban streetscape of Sri Lanka. PLOS ONE, 17(8), e0272074.

MTH_SEG.source_paper: Liang Cheng et al. - 2017 - Use of Tencent Street View Imagery for Visual Percep

MTH_M2F.name: Mask2Former
MTH_M2F.definition: A universal image segmentation architecture capable of addressing semantic, instance, and panoptic segmentation tasks simultaneously. It utilizes a Masked-attention Mask Transformer to extract localized features by constraining cross-attention within predicted mask regions, significantly improving performance on difficult segmentation tasks compared to specialized models.

supporting_papers.citation: Sánchez, I. A. V., & Labib, S. M. (2024). Accessing eye-level greenness visibility from open-source street view images: A methodological development and implementation in multi-city and multi-country contexts. Sustainable Cities and Society, 103, 105262.

MTH_MSK.name: Mask R-CNN (Mask Region-based Convolutional Neural Network)
MTH_MSK.definition: A deep neural network architecture used for instance segmentation. It extends the Faster R-CNN object detection model by adding a parallel branch for predicting segmentation masks on each Region of Interest (RoI), allowing the model to detect objects and simultaneously generate a high-quality pixel-level mask for each instance.

supporting_papers.citation: Ma, H., Xu, Q., & Zhang, Y. (2023). High or low? Exploring the restorative effects of visual levels on campus spaces using machine learning and street view imagery. Urban Forestry & Urban Greening, 88, 128087.

MTH_BOX.name: Boxplot (Box-and-Whisker Plot)
MTH_BOX.definition: A standardized statistical method for graphically displaying the distribution of a dataset based on a five-number summary: the minimum, first quartile (Q1), median, third quartile (Q3), and maximum. It is effectively used to identify outliers and compare distributions between different groups of data.

supporting_papers.citation: Kawshalya, L. W. G., Weerasinghe, U. G. D., & Chandrasekara, D. P. (2022). The impact of visual complexity on perceived safety and comfort of the users: A study on urban streetscape of Sri Lanka. PLOS ONE, 17(8), e0272074.

Liu, Z., Ma, X., Hu, L., Liu, Y., Lu, S., Chen, H., & Tan, Z. (2022). Nonlinear Cooling Effect of Street Green Space Morphology: Evidence from a Gradient Boosting Decision Tree and Explainable Machine Learning Approach. Land, 11(12), 2220.

MTH_GIN.name: Graph Isomorphism Network
MTH_GIN.definition: A powerful variant of Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) designed to achieve maximum discriminative power, theoretically comparable to the Weisfeiler-Lehman graph isomorphism test. GINs aggregate neighbor features using injective functions, allowing them to distinguish between different graph structures that other GNN architectures might conflate.

supporting_papers.citation: Guo, X., Liu, C., Bi, S., & Tang, Y. (2025). Identification of Inequities in Green Visibility and Ways to Increase Greenery in Neighborhoods: A Case Study of Wuhan, China. Applied Sciences, 15(2), 742.

MTH_FCN.name: Fully Convolutional Network
MTH_FCN.definition: A deep learning architecture commonly used for semantic segmentation. Unlike traditional Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) that end with fully connected layers for classification, FCNs consist entirely of convolutional layers. This allows the network to accept input images of arbitrary sizes and produce output maps of corresponding dimensions.

supporting_papers.citation: Rui, Q., & Cheng, H. (2023). Quantifying the spatial quality of urban streets with open street view images: A case study of the main urban area of Fuzhou. Ecological Indicators, 156, 111204.

Wang, K., Fang, X., Ma, Y., Xue, S., & Yin, S. (2022). Assessing Effects of Urban Greenery on the Regulation Mechanism of Microclimate and Outdoor Thermal Comfort during Winter in China's Cold Region. Land, 11(9), 1442.

Dai, L., Zheng, C., Dong, Z., Yao, Y., Wang, R., Zhang, X., Ren, S., Zhang, J., Song, X., & Guan, Q. (2021). Analyzing the correlation between visual space and residents' psychology in Wuhan, China using street-view images and deep-learning technique. City and Environment Interactions, 11, 100069.

MTH_PAN_FPN.name: Panoptic Feature Pyramid Network
MTH_PAN_FPN.definition: A computer vision architecture designed for panoptic segmentation, which unifies semantic segmentation (identifying background 'stuff') and instance segmentation (identifying distinct 'things'). It employs a Feature Pyramid Network (FPN) backbone to extract multi-scale features, enabling robust detection and segmentation of objects across varying sizes and resolutions.

supporting_papers.citation: Zhang, Y., Li, S., Dong, R., Deng, H., Fu, X., Wang, C., Yu, T., Jia, T., & Zhao, J. (2021). Quantifying physical and psychological perceptions of urban scenes using deep learning. Land Use Policy, 111, 105762.

Wang, M., Haworth, J., Chen, H., Liu, Y., & Shi, Z. (2024). Investigating the potential of crowdsourced street-level imagery in understanding the spatiotemporal dynamics of cities: A case study of walkability in Inner London. Cities, 153, 105243.

MTH_SGF.name: Savitzky-Golay Filter
MTH_SGF.definition: A digital signal processing method used to smooth data and increase the signal-to-noise ratio without greatly distorting the signal. It works by fitting successive sub-sets of adjacent data points with a low-degree polynomial by the method of linear least squares, preserving features like peak height and width better than moving averages.

supporting_papers.citation: Ogawa, Y., Oki, T., Zhao, C., Sekimoto, Y., & Shimizu, C. (2024). Evaluating the subjective perceptions of streetscapes using street-view images. Landscape and Urban Planning, 247, 105073.

MTH_IDW.name: Inverse Distance Weighting
MTH_IDW.definition: A deterministic spatial interpolation method used to estimate values at unknown locations based on known sample points. It operates on the assumption that things that are closer to one another are more alike than those that are farther apart; therefore, the influence of a known point on an interpolated value diminishes as the distance between them increases.

supporting_papers.citation: Meng, Y., Xing, H., Yuan, Y., Wong, M. S., & Fan, K. (2020). Sensing urban poverty: From the perspective of human perception-based greenery and open-space landscapes. Computers, Environment and Urban Systems, 84, 101544.

MTH_HSI.name: Hyperspectral Imaging
MTH_HSI.definition: An imaging technique that collects and processes information from across the electromagnetic spectrum. unlike the human eye or standard cameras that capture three bands (RGB), HSI divides the spectrum into many narrow, continuous spectral bands. This results in a unique spectral signature for each pixel, enabling precise material identification and chemical analysis.

supporting_papers.citation: Dong, R., Zhang, Y., & Zhao, J. (2018). How Green Are the Streets Within the Sixth Ring Road of Beijing? An Analysis Based on Tencent Street View Pictures and the Green View Index. International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health, 15(7), 1367.

MTH_EWM.name: Entropy Weight Method
MTH_EWM.definition: An objective weighting method used in multi-criteria decision analysis and statistics. It determines the weight of various indicators by calculating their information entropy, which measures the amount of useful information provided by the data. A lower entropy value implies greater variation and thus a higher weight in the evaluation model.

supporting_papers.citation: Tao, Y., Wang, Y., Wang, X., Tian, G., & Zhang, S. (2022). Measuring the Correlation between Human Activity Density and Streetscape Perceptions: An Analysis Based on Baidu Street View Images in Zhengzhou, China. Land, 11(3), 400.

MTH_BSV.name: Baidu Street View Imagery Analysis
MTH_BSV.definition: A geospatial research method utilizing panoramic 360-degree street-level imagery provided by Baidu Maps. In urban analytics and environmental studies, this method is employed to extract visual features of the built environment—such as green view indices, sky openness, and building facades—often using computer vision techniques to assess urban quality, walkability, and spatial characteristics in regions where Google Street View is unavailable.

supporting_papers.citation: Xiao, C., Shi, Q., & Gu, C.-J. (2021). Assessing the Spatial Distribution Pattern of Street Greenery and Its Relationship with Socioeconomic Status and the Built Environment in Shanghai, China. Land, 10(8), 871.
Xu, H., Lu, H., & Liu, S. (2024). Online Street View-Based Approach for Sky View Factor Estimation: A Case Study of Nanjing, China. Applied Sciences, 14(5), 2133.

Zhang, A., Zhai, S., Liu, X., Song, G., & Feng, Y. (2022). Investigating the Association between Streetscapes and Mental Health in Zhanjiang, China: Using Baidu Street View Images and Deep Learning. International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health, 19(24), 16634.

Chen, J., Zhou, C., & Li, F. (2020). Quantifying the green view indicator for assessing urban greening quality: An analysis based on Internet-crawling street view data. Ecological Indicators, 113, 106192.

MTH_REV.name: Systematic Literature Review
MTH_REV.definition: A rigorous and reproducible research methodology used to identify, evaluate, and synthesize existing scholarly work produced by researchers, scholars, and practitioners. This method aims to provide a comprehensive overview of the current state of knowledge on a specific topic, identify research gaps, and establish a theoretical framework for future studies by critically analyzing patterns and trends in prior literature.

MTH_HSV.name: Hue, Saturation, Value Color Model
MTH_HSV.definition: A color representation method used in image processing and computer vision that defines colors based on three components: Hue (color type), Saturation (intensity/purity), and Value (brightness). Unlike the RGB model, HSV separates chromatic information from luma (intensity), making it a preferred method for color-based segmentation and feature extraction in scene analysis, as it is more robust to changes in external lighting conditions.

MTH_MED_ANL.name: Mediation Analysis
MTH_MED_ANL.definition: A statistical method used to elucidate the mechanism underlying an observed relationship between an independent variable and a dependent variable via the inclusion of a third explanatory variable, known as a mediator. This analysis seeks to identify the extent to which the effect of the independent variable is direct versus how much is transmitted indirectly through the mediator, offering deeper insights into causal pathways.

SRC_FLD.name: Field Survey
SRC_FLD.definition: SRC_FLD involves the direct observation and collection of data within the actual physical environment rather than through remote sensing or simulations. This method encompasses on-site measurements, photography, observation of user behavior, and physical audits of site conditions. Field surveys provide ground-truth data that captures the nuances of the genius loci, sensory inputs (sound, smell), and ephemeral conditions that laboratory or digital analyses might miss. It ensures the validity of the dataset by verifying real-world conditions against theoretical models.

SRC_PAN.name: Panoramic Images
SRC_PAN.definition: SRC_PAN refers to 360-degree panoramic imagery, typically captured using omnidirectional cameras or by stitching together multiple images. These wide-angle visual representations provide a comprehensive, immersive view of a physical environment, allowing for the assessment of urban streetscapes and environmental features from a user-centric perspective. In computational analysis, these images are often projected into equirectangular formats to facilitate semantic segmentation and feature extraction.
SRC_PAN.first_confirmed_by: Zhao, X., & Lin, G. (2024). Research on the Perception Evaluation of Urban Green Spaces Using Panoramic Images and Deep Learning: A Case Study of Zhujiang Park in Guangzhou. Landscape Architecture Frontiers, 12(6), 007-024.

SRC_SIM.name: Simulation
SRC_SIM.definition: SRC_SIM denotes computer-generated imagery (CGI) derived from virtual simulations or game engines. Unlike real-world photography, these datasets offer controlled environments where lighting, weather, and object placement can be manipulated precisely. This allows researchers to train machine learning models on synthetic data to improve generalization or to test urban design scenarios before implementation. It bridges the gap between theoretical models and visual reality in spatial analysis.

SRC_PLP.name: Property Listing Platforms
SRC_PLP.definition: Refers to data sourced from online real estate marketplaces and digital listing services (e.g., Zillow, Rightmove, Airbnb). As a data source, these platforms provide granular, often real-time information regarding housing asking prices, rental rates, structural characteristics, and amenities. Researchers utilize this data for hedonic price modeling, market trend analysis, and urban analytics to supplement or replace traditional administrative housing datasets which may be less frequently updated.

SRC_LIT.name: Literature Review
SRC_LIT.definition: Data or parameters derived from the systematic review and synthesis of existing academic publications, books, and peer-reviewed articles. In modeling and simulation studies, this source involves extracting qualitative findings, coefficients, or validation metrics from prior research rather than collecting primary raw data. It is often used to establish baselines, validate theoretical frameworks, or conduct meta-analyses.

SRC_BDM.name: Building Information/Energy Model
SRC_BDM.definition: Refers to data generated through detailed physical simulations of buildings, such as those produced by Building Information Modeling (BIM) or Building Energy Modeling (BEM) software (e.g., EnergyPlus, Revit). Unlike empirical measurements, this data source relies on physics-based equations and architectural parameters to predict building performance, energy consumption, and thermal behavior, providing inputs for theoretical analysis when sensor data is unavailable.

SRC_MAP.name: Cartographic Maps
SRC_MAP.definition: Information extracted from traditional visual representations of geography, such as digitized historical maps, topographic sheets, or thematic paper maps. As a data source, this involves the manual or digital extraction (digitization) of features like historical land use, boundary changes, or physical infrastructure that may not exist in modern vector databases. It allows researchers to incorporate historical spatial contexts into modern analyses.

supporting_papers.citation: Sánchez, I. A. V., & Labib, S. M. (2024). Accessing eye-level greenness visibility from open-source street view images: A methodological development and implementation in multi-city and multi-country contexts. Sustainable Cities and Society, 103, 105262.

SRC_MAP_API.name: Map Application Programming Interface
SRC_MAP_API.definition: A set of protocols and tools that allow researchers to programmatically interact with web-based mapping services (such as Google Maps, Baidu Maps, or OpenStreetMap). This method is essential for harvesting geospatial data, geocoding addresses, rendering interactive visualizations, and performing spatial queries, enabling the integration of location-based intelligence into urban planning and social science research.

supporting_papers.citation: Wang, M., Haworth, J., Chen, H., Liu, Y., & Shi, Z. (2024). Investigating the potential of crowdsourced street-level imagery in understanding the spatiotemporal dynamics of cities: A case study of walkability in Inner London. Cities, 153, 105243.

SRC_NA.name: Not Applicable
SRC_NA.definition: Indicates that the data source is not applicable, not reported, or cannot be determined for this record.

TOL_PSP.name: PSPNet
TOL_PSP.definition: TOL_PSP refers to the Pyramid Scene Parsing Network, a deep learning architecture designed for pixel-level semantic segmentation tasks. It utilizes a pyramid pooling module to aggregate global context information from different sub-regions of an image. By capturing local and global context simultaneously, PSPNet effectively handles complex scenes where objects have varying scales. This capability makes it particularly robust for analyzing urban environments and identifying distinct features such as vegetation, roads, and buildings.

TOL_FCN.name: Fully Convolutional Network
TOL_FCN.definition: TOL_FCN stands for Fully Convolutional Network, a neural network architecture that pioneered end-to-end semantic segmentation. Unlike traditional Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) that use fully connected layers for classification, FCNs replace these with convolutional layers to output spatial maps instead of classification scores. This allows the network to accept input images of arbitrary sizes and produce dense, pixel-wise predictions, making it a foundational tool for image processing and spatial analysis tasks.

TOL_EFN.name: EfficientNet
TOL_EFN.definition: TOL_EFN refers to EfficientNet, a family of convolutional neural networks designed to achieve high accuracy while optimizing computational efficiency. It utilizes a compound scaling method that uniformly scales network width, depth, and image resolution using a simple, fixed set of coefficients. This balanced approach allows EfficientNet to extract complex visual features with fewer parameters and FLOPs compared to previous architectures, making it ideal for resource-constrained environments or large-scale image processing.

TOL_PYT.name: PyTorch
TOL_PYT.definition: TOL_PYT represents PyTorch, an open-source machine learning library primarily developed by Meta AI. It is widely used for applications in computer vision and natural language processing due to its flexibility and dynamic computation graph system. PyTorch provides a comprehensive ecosystem for building deep learning models, offering robust tensor computing with GPU acceleration. Its intuitive interface and extensive community support make it a standard framework for academic research and industrial AI development.

TOL_ARC.name: ArcGIS
TOL_ARC.definition: TOL_ARC refers to ArcGIS, a comprehensive Geographic Information System (GIS) software suite developed by Esri. It is used for mapping, data management, and spatial reasoning. The platform allows users to create, analyze, and visualize geographic data, enabling the discovery of patterns and trends within spatial contexts. In urban research, ArcGIS is essential for processing geospatial layers, calculating spatial metrics, and integrating results from machine learning models into cartographic representations.

TOL_XCP.definition: A deep convolutional neural network architecture based on Depthwise Separable Convolutions, used for image segmentation.

TOL_MMS.first_confirmed_by: Zheng, Z., Chen, L., Zeng, M., Liu, W., & Chen, H. (2024). TOL_CAM.name: CAMPUS (Computer Aided Material Preselection by Uniform Standards)
TOL_CAM.definition: A recognized software database and information system for the plastics and materials industry. It provides comparable and standardized material property data (such as thermal, mechanical, and processing properties) based on uniform international standards. In the context of building modeling and engineering, this tool is used to select appropriate materials for simulation inputs, ensuring that the physical properties used in models accurately reflect real-world material behaviors.

TOL_IMGJ.name: ImageJ
TOL_IMGJ.definition: An open-source, Java-based image processing program developed at the National Institutes of Health (NIH). It is designed for analyzing multidimensional scientific images and is widely used for biological and materials science image analysis.

TOL_GIS.name: Geographic Information System
TOL_GIS.definition: A computer system designed to capture, store, manipulate, analyze, manage, and present spatial or geographic data. It integrates various types of data layers using maps and 3D scenes to understand relationships and patterns in geography.

TOL_UNSPECIFIED.definition: Indicates that the specific tool, software, or algorithm used to generate or process the data was not declared, recorded, or provided in the source metadata.

TOL_SGF.name: Semi-Global Filtering (or Matching)
TOL_SGF.definition: A computer vision technique used for stereo matching and depth estimation (often abbreviated as SGM or SGF). Unlike deep learning approaches, it optimizes an energy function over the entire image path to produce dense disparity maps, often used in photogrammetry and remote sensing.

supporting_papers.citation: Zhao, X., Lu, Y., & Lin, G. (2024). An integrated deep learning approach for assessing the visual qualities of built environments utilizing street view images. Engineering Applications of Artificial Intelligence, 130, 107805.

TOL_DPL.name: Deep Learning
TOL_DPL.definition: A broad subset of machine learning based on artificial neural networks with representation learning. It involves training models with multiple layers to extract higher-level features from raw input (such as images) progressively.

supporting_papers.citation: Fang, Q.L., Inoue, T., Xie, Z.Q., & Liu, Q. (2022). Street Sky Openness Estimation Based on Deep Learning. p.9, Table 5.

TOL_RES_NET.name: Residual Neural Network (ResNet)
TOL_RES_NET.definition: A specific artificial neural network architecture characterized by the use of skip connections (or shortcuts) that allow gradients to flow more easily during training. This architecture specifically addresses the vanishing gradient problem in deep networks.

TOL_UNK.name: Unknown
TOL_UNK.definition: Indicates that the tool or method used is not known. This differs from 'Unspecified' in that the information exists but is missing or lost, whereas 'Unspecified' suggests it was never declared.

TOL_RSN.name: RefineNet (Refinement Neural Network)
TOL_RSN.definition: A deep learning architecture designed for high-resolution semantic segmentation. It uses a multi-path refinement network to exploit features at various levels of abstraction, often serving as an alternative to DeepLab or ResNet-based segmentation approaches.

TOL_WIN.name: Windows Environment
TOL_WIN.definition: Refers to the use of the Microsoft Windows operating system ecosystem as the primary tool environment for processing the data, possibly implying the use of Windows-exclusive software applications.

supporting_papers.citation: Wang, K., Fang, X., Ma, Y., Xue, S., & Yin, S. (2022). Assessing Effects of Urban Greenery on the Regulation Mechanism of Microclimate and Outdoor Thermal Comfort during Winter in China's Cold Region. Land, 11(9), 1442.

TOL_DL3.name: DeepLab Version 3
TOL_DL3.definition: A state-of-the-art semantic segmentation model developed by Google. It employs atrous (dilated) convolution to explicitly control the resolution of features computed by Deep Convolutional Neural Networks and capture multi-scale context.

TOL_DLV.name: DeepLab Version 3 (Generic)
TOL_DLV.definition: Refers to the DeepLab family of semantic segmentation architectures (specifically V3). It is designed to label every pixel in an image with a corresponding class, widely used in satellite imagery analysis.

TOL_GPU.name: Graphics Processing Unit
TOL_GPU.definition: A specialized electronic circuit designed to manipulate and alter memory to accelerate the creation of images in a frame buffer intended for output to a display device. In modern scientific computing and data analysis, GPUs are extensively utilized for their parallel processing capabilities, significantly accelerating machine learning algorithms, deep learning training, and complex mathematical simulations compared to standard Central Processing Units (CPUs).

supporting_papers.citation: Wu, R., Fang, X., Brown, R., Liu, S., & Zhao, H. (2023). Establishing a link between complex courtyard spaces and thermal comfort: A major advancement in evidence-based design. Building and Environment, 245, 110852.

TOL_HMA.name: Human-Machine Adversarial Model

supporting_papers.citation: Qi, S. (2024). Utilizing Semantic Segmentation to Analyse Google Street View Imagery for Health-Oriented Urban Planning. Geoforum Perspektiv, 44, 39-46.

TOL_HMA.definition: A scoring framework combining human evaluation with machine learning (often Random Forest) to predict perception scores for large datasets.
TOL_HMA.first_confirmed_by: Lei, Y.; Zhou, H.; Xue, L.; Yuan, L.; Liu, Y.; Wang, M.; Wang, C. Evaluating and Comparing Human Perceptions of Streets in Two Megacities by Integrating Street-View Images, Deep Learning, and Space Syntax. Buildings 2024, 14, 1847.

TOL_HRN.name: High-Resolution Network (HRNet)
TOL_HRN.definition: A deep learning architecture designed to maintain high-resolution representations through the entire feature extraction process. Unlike traditional networks that downsample and then upsample, HRNet connects high-to-low resolution subnetworks in parallel. This method is highly effective for position-sensitive tasks such as semantic segmentation and object detection in urban scene analysis.

TOL_INT.name: Integrated Mixed Methods
TOL_INT.definition: A methodological approach that synthesizes quantitative and qualitative data sources or combines multiple analytical techniques to address complex research questions. In urban studies, this often involves integrating geospatial data with social surveys or combining remote sensing with ground-level observations to provide a holistic understanding of spatial phenomena that single-method approaches cannot achieve.

supporting_papers.citation: An, S., Jang, H., Kim, H., Song, Y., & Ahn, K. (2023). Assessment of street-level greenness and its association with housing prices in a metropolitan area. Scientific Reports, 13(1).

TOL_MSK.name: Mask R-CNN (Mask Region-based Convolutional Neural Network)
TOL_MSK.definition: A deep neural network architecture used for instance segmentation. It extends the Faster R-CNN object detection model by adding a parallel branch for predicting segmentation masks on each Region of Interest (RoI), allowing the model to detect objects and simultaneously generate a high-quality pixel-level mask for each instance.

supporting_papers.citation: Ma, H., Xu, Q., & Zhang, Y. (2023). High or low? Exploring the restorative effects of visual levels on campus spaces using machine learning and street view imagery. Urban Forestry & Urban Greening, 88, 128087.

TOL_OCV.name: Open Circuit Voltage
TOL_OCV.definition: A measurement method used primarily in electrochemistry and battery management systems to determine the electric potential difference between two terminals of a device when disconnected from any circuit. In data modeling and non-destructive testing, OCV curves are utilized to estimate the state of charge (SoC) or health of energy storage devices.

TOL_SEG_NET.name: SegNet (Semantic Segmentation Network)
TOL_SEG_NET.definition: A deep convolutional encoder-decoder architecture specifically designed for semantic pixel-wise image segmentation. The core method involves an encoder network to generate feature maps and a corresponding decoder network that upsamples these maps to produce a dense classification output, widely used for understanding scene geometry and content in autonomous systems.

UNT_IDX.name: Index
UNT_IDX.definition: UNT_IDX indicates a normalized index value, typically a dimensionless number used to quantify a specific phenomenon relative to a standard scale. In remote sensing and urban analysis, indices like the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) or Green View Index (GVI) are calculated to standardize measurements, ranging often between -1 and 1 or 0 and 100. This standardization facilitates the comparison of spatial features across different locations and time periods.

UNT_SCR.name: Score
UNT_SCR.definition: A score is defined as a quantitative 'index' or 'value' derived from the automated analysis of street view images. The text specifically describes calculating a 'Green View Index' (GVI) by counting the proportion of specific colored pixels, as well as generating values for 'Sky-Openness' and 'Visual Entropy.' These calculated scores function as objective data points to evaluate specific visual characteristics of streetscapes, replacing complex manual information acquisition.

UNT_MTR.name: Meters
UNT_MTR.definition: UNT_MTR signifies the meter, the fundamental unit of length in the International System of Units (SI). In geospatial and urban studies, it serves as the primary metric for defining distances, heights, and spatial resolutions. Whether measuring the width of street canyons, the height of buildings, or the distance between amenities, quantifying these dimensions in meters ensures consistency and compatibility with global cartographic standards and spatial databases.

UNT_DEG.name: Degrees
UNT_DEG.definition: UNT_DEG refers to degrees, a unit of angular measurement used to define geographic coordinates (latitude and longitude) and geometric angles. In the context of panoramic imagery and field of view (FoV), degrees quantify the extent of the observable world captured by a sensor. Furthermore, in spatial analysis, degrees are essential for calculating slopes, determining aspect, and establishing the orientation of urban features relative to cardinal directions.
