UNT_UGM3.name: Micrograms per Cubic Meter
UNT_UGM3.definition: A unit of concentration primarily used in environmental science and air quality monitoring to measure the mass of a substance (in micrograms) present within one cubic meter of air. It is the standard metric for quantifying the levels of particulate matter (such as PM2.5 and PM10) and various gaseous pollutants to assess compliance with health standards and environmental regulations.

UNT_OR.name: Odds Ratio
UNT_OR.definition: A statistic that quantifies the strength of the association between two events, A and B. It represents the odds that an outcome will occur given a particular exposure, compared to the odds of the outcome occurring in the absence of that exposure. It is widely used in case-control studies, epidemiology, and logistic regression analysis to determine risk factors and the likelihood of outcomes.

UNT_RTO.name: Ratio
UNT_RTO.definition: A relationship between two numbers indicating how many times the first number contains the second. It compares two quantities by division and is fundamental in mathematics and science for establishing proportional relationships, such as stoichiometric balances in chemistry, financial liquidity metrics, or demographic comparisons. It is essentially a dimensionless value resulting from the division of two quantities with the same unit.

UNT_NA.name: Not Applicable / Not Available
UNT_NA.definition: A standard designation in data collection and database management indicating that a specific data point is missing, irrelevant, or does not apply to the specific observation. It is distinct from a zero value; properly handling 'NA' entries is crucial in statistical analysis to prevent skewing results, as these placeholders must often be excluded or imputed during data processing.

UNT_COE.name: Coefficient
UNT_COE.definition: A numerical or constant factor placed before and multiplying the variable in an algebraic expression (e.g., the '4' in '4x'). In broader scientific contexts, it refers to a constant value representing a specific property of a substance or system under defined conditions, such as the coefficient of friction, correlation coefficient, or coefficient of expansion.

UNT_WGT.name: Weight
UNT_WGT.definition: In physics, the force exerted on an object due to gravity, calculated as mass times gravitational acceleration. In statistical analysis and data science, 'weight' refers to a value assigned to a data item to emphasize its relative importance or frequency in a computation, often used to correct for sampling bias or to prioritize specific variables in machine learning models.

UNT_STD_BET.name: Standardized Beta Coefficient
UNT_STD_BET.definition: A regression coefficient obtained after standardizing all variables in a regression model (rescaling them to have a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1). This allows researchers to compare the relative strength of the effect of each independent variable on the dependent variable, regardless of the different units of measurement used for the original predictors.

UNT_CNT.name: Count / Frequency
UNT_CNT.definition: A fundamental statistical unit representing the absolute frequency or number of discrete entities (such as buildings, points of interest, or pedestrian observations) present within a specific spatial unit or dataset. It serves as a raw baseline for calculating densities and distributions.

UNT_SD.name: Standard Deviation
UNT_SD.definition: A statistical measure of the amount of variation or dispersion in a set of values relative to the mean. In urban analytics, it is used to quantify the heterogeneity of spatial attributes, such as building heights, street widths, or population density across a specific area.

UNT_KM2.name: Square Kilometer
UNT_KM2.definition: A standard metric unit of area measurement used to define the spatial extent of urban zones. It is commonly employed as the denominator in density calculations (e.g., population per km²) to normalize data across regions of varying sizes for comparative analysis.

UNT_R_VAL.name: Correlation Coefficient (R-Value)
UNT_R_VAL.definition: A statistical metric (typically Pearson’s or Spearman’s r) that quantifies the strength and direction of the linear relationship between two spatial variables. Values range from -1 to 1, indicating the degree to which one urban metric predicts or moves in tandem with another.

PRF_HLT.definition: Health and wellbeing outcomes including physical health indicators, psychological health, and restorative benefits.

PRF_SOC.definition: Social outcomes including interaction/cohesion and social equity in access to and benefits from environments.

PRF_NA.name: Performance - Not Applicable
PRF_NA.definition: A designation used in data sets when a specific performance metric cannot be calculated, is missing, or is irrelevant for a given observation. In statistical analysis of urban performance, this serves as a placeholder to ensure data integrity, indicating that the requisite features for evaluation were absent (e.g., a water performance metric in a desert plaza) or that the data point was corrupted.

supporting_papers.citation: Ki, D., & Lee, S. (2021). Analyzing the effects of Green View Index of neighborhood streets on walking time using Google Street View and deep learning. Landscape and Urban Planning, 205, 103920.

PRF_NA.dimension_merge_note: This main performance dimension consolidates previously separate dimensions for a 7-dimension scheme.

PRS_STR.name: Stress Reduction

supporting_papers.citation: Lee, D.H. et al. (2024). A Review on Recent Deep Learning-Based Semantic Segmentation for Urban Greenness Measurement. Sensors, 24, 2245.
Li, C., Du, C., Ge, S., & Tong, T. (2023). An eye-tracking study on visual perception of vegetation permeability in virtual reality forest exposure. Frontiers in Public Health, 11.

PRS_STR.first_confirmed_by: Zhao, X., & Lin, G. (2024). Research on the Perception Evaluation of Urban Green Spaces Using Panoramic Images and Deep Learning: A Case Study of Zhujiang Park in Guangzhou. Landscape Architecture Frontiers, 12(6), 007-024.

PRS_AES.name: Aesthetic Appreciation
PRS_AES.definition: PRS_AES denotes the cognitive and emotional evaluation of the visual quality of an environment. It goes beyond simple preference to include judgements of harmony, order, and artistic merit. In landscape research, this variable assesses how specific design elements—such as architectural style, vegetation complexity, and color palette—contribute to a pleasurable visual experience. It acts as a key determinant in how users value and engage with urban settings.

supporting_papers.citation: Gao, L., Xiang, X., Chen, W., Nong, R., Zhang, Q., Chen, X., & Chen, Y. (2024). Research on Urban Street Spatial Quality Based on Street View Image Segmentation. Sustainability, 16(16), 7184.

Hu, A., Yabuki, N., Fukuda, T., Kaga, H., Takeda, S., & Matsuo, K. (2023). Harnessing multiple data sources and emerging technologies for comprehensive urban green space evaluation. Cities, 143, 104562.

PRS_AES.first_confirmed_by: Hu, A., Yabuki, N., Fukuda, T., Kaga, H., Takeda, S., & Matsuo, K. (2023). Harnessing multiple data sources and emerging technologies for comprehensive urban green space evaluation. Cities, 143, 104562.

PRS_APP.name: Attractiveness
PRS_APP.definition: PRS_APP refers to the visual appeal or 'pull' factor of a location, indicating how inviting a space appears to observers. Unlike pure aesthetic appreciation, attractiveness often implies a behavioral intent or desire to visit and inhabit the space. It is a composite measure influenced by greenery, cleanliness, architectural distinctiveness, and vibrancy. This metric is frequently used to predict property values, tourism potential, and pedestrian flows.
PRS_APP.first_confirmed_by: Zhao, X., & Lin, G. (2024). Research on the Perception Evaluation of Urban Green Spaces Using Panoramic Images and Deep Learning: A Case Study of Zhujiang Park in Guangzhou. Landscape Architecture Frontiers, 12(6), 007-024.

PRS_DIV.name: Diversity/Richness
PRS_DIV.definition: PRS_DIV refers to the subjective assessment of the visual complexity and variety present within a physical environment. In the context of environmental psychology and urban planning, this variable captures the richness of features, such as the abundance of plant species, variations in structural forms, or the density of visual stimuli. It serves as an indicator of how users perceive the ecological or aesthetic complexity of a space, distinguishing between monotonous settings and those offering high sensory stimulation and structural diversity.

supporting_papers.citation: Liu, W., Hu, X., Song, Z., & Yuan, X. (2023). Identifying the integrated visual characteristics of greenway landscape: A focus on human perception. Sustainable Cities and Society, 99, 104937.

PRS_DIV.first_confirmed_by: Zhao, X., & Lin, G. (2024). Research on the Perception Evaluation of Urban Green Spaces Using Panoramic Images and Deep Learning: A Case Study of Zhujiang Park in Guangzhou. Landscape Architecture Frontiers, 12(6), 007-024.

PRS_SOC.name: Social Interaction
PRS_SOC.definition: PRS_SOC designates the capacity of a specific environment to facilitate interpersonal relationships and community engagement. This measure evaluates the perceived affordances of a space for social gatherings, such as the availability of communal areas, seating, and layouts that promote visibility. It reflects the degree to which an individual believes a setting supports various forms of social activity, ranging from casual encounters to structured group interactions, thereby contributing to community cohesion and perceived social capital.

supporting_papers.citation: Chen, M., Cai, Y., Guo, S., Sun, R., Song, Y., & Shen, X. (2024). Evaluating implied urban nature vitality in San Francisco: An interdisciplinary approach combining census data, street view images, and social media analysis. Urban Forestry & Urban Greening, 95, 128289.

PRS_SOC.first_confirmed_by: Chen, M., Cai, Y., Guo, S., Sun, R., Song, Y., & Shen, X. (2024). Evaluating implied urban nature vitality in San Francisco: An interdisciplinary approach combining census data, street view images, and social media analysis. Urban Forestry & Urban Greening, 95, 128289.

PRS_COL.name: Cooling Effect
PRS_COL.definition: PRS_COL represents the perceived capacity of an environmental feature, particularly green or blue infrastructure, to mitigate heat and improve thermal comfort. This variable assesses the subjective experience of temperature reduction attributed to factors like shading, evapotranspiration, or wind flow modification. Unlike objective meteorological data, this measure focuses on human thermal sensation and the relief provided by landscape elements during periods of high heat, playing a critical role in user satisfaction and outdoor space utilization.

supporting_papers.citation: Chan, T.-C., Lee, P.-H., Lee, Y.-T., & Tang, J.-H. (2024). Exploring the spatial association between the distribution of temperature and urban morphology with green view index. PLOS ONE, 19(5), e0301921.

Li, X., Ratti, C., & Seiferling, I. (2018). Quantifying the shade provision of street trees in urban landscape: A case study in Boston, USA, using Google Street View. Landscape and Urban Planning, 169, 81–91.

Li, B., Xing, H., Cao, D., Yang, G., & Zhang, H. (2022). Exploring the Effects of Roadside Vegetation on the Urban Thermal Environment Using Street View Images. International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health, 19(3), 1272.

Liu, Z., Ma, X., Hu, L., Liu, Y., Lu, S., Chen, H., & Tan, Z. (2022). Nonlinear Cooling Effect of Street Green Space Morphology: Evidence from a Gradient Boosting Decision Tree and Explainable Machine Learning Approach. Land, 11(12), 2220.

Ni, Y., Lin, L., Xia, H., & Wang, X. (2025). Urban Street Greening and Resident Comfort: An Integrated Approach Based on High-Precision Shadow Distribution and Facade Visual Assessment. Sustainability, 17(3), 1026.
Xin, B., Zhu, C., Geng, J., & Liu, Y. (2024). Emotional Perceptions of Thermal Comfort for People Exposed to Green Spaces Characterized Using Streetscapes in Urban Parks. Land, 13(9), 1515.

PRS_COL.first_confirmed_by: Chan, T.-C., Lee, P.-H., Lee, Y.-T., & Tang, J.-H. (2024). Exploring the spatial association between the distribution of temperature and urban morphology with green view index. PLOS ONE, 19(5), e0301921.

PRS_MOB.name: Mobility Behavior
PRS_MOB.definition: Behaviors related to movement and transport choice (cycling, walking, driving).
PRS_MOB.first_confirmed_by: Chen, Y., Chen, Y., Tu, W., & Zeng, X. (2020). Is eye-level greening associated with the use of dockless shared bicycles? Urban Forestry & Urban Greening, 51, 126690.

PRS_SCL.name: Scale of Presence
PRS_SCL.definition: A subdimension measuring the volume or quantity of media coverage, social media mentions, or data points associated with a specific urban topic, indicating the magnitude of public attention or discourse surrounding the subject.

supporting_papers.citation: Cai, M., Xiang, L., & Ng, E. (2023). How does the visual environment influence pedestrian physiological stress? Evidence from high-density cities using ambulatory technology and spatial machine learning. Sustainable Cities and Society, 96, 104695.

PRS_QUA.name: Quality of Presence
PRS_QUA.definition: An assessment of the sentiment, source authority, or influence level of the data or media coverage recorded, distinguishing between high-impact, substantive engagement and low-level or negative noise.

PRS_DIS.name: District Distribution
PRS_DIS.definition: A spatial subdimension analyzing the geographic spread or concentration of a specific phenomenon (such as service availability, public sentiment, or environmental factors) across different administrative districts or neighborhoods within the city.

supporting_papers.citation: Li, X., Liu, Q., Liu, X., & Ren, Y. (2025). Greener is healthier: Unraveling the distinction of health impacts of urban green indicators in Wuhan, China. Sustainable Cities and Society, 125, 106318.

PRS_HEA.name: Health Dimension
PRS_HEA.definition: A specific category tracking performance or public perception related to physical health outcomes, healthcare facility availability, disease prevalence, and public health indicators within the urban environment.

PRS_PSY.name: Psychological Dimension
PRS_PSY.definition: A measure of the mental well-being, stress levels, or emotional sentiment of the urban population, often derived from survey data or sentiment analysis of social media interactions regarding city life.

supporting_papers.citation: Dong, R., Zhang, Y., & Zhao, J. (2018). How Green Are the Streets Within the Sixth Ring Road of Beijing? An Analysis Based on Tencent Street View Pictures and the Green View Index. International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health, 15(7), 1367.
Ogawa, Y., Oki, T., Zhao, C., Sekimoto, Y., & Shimizu, C. (2024). Evaluating the subjective perceptions of streetscapes using street-view images. Landscape and Urban Planning, 247, 105073.

Wang, K., Fang, X., Ma, Y., Xue, S., & Yin, S. (2022). Assessing Effects of Urban Greenery on the Regulation Mechanism of Microclimate and Outdoor Thermal Comfort during Winter in China's Cold Region. Land, 11(9), 1442.

PRS_LGT.name: Light and Nighttime Economy
PRS_LGT.definition: An indicator derived from nighttime luminosity data or street lighting coverage, used to assess economic activity, urban expansion, public safety, and the vibrancy of the city's environment after dark.

supporting_papers.citation: Zheng, Y., Lan, S., Zhao, J., Liu, Y., He, S., & Liu, C. (2024). Modeling the Effect of Greenways' Multilevel Visual Characteristics on Thermal Perception in Summer Based on Bayesian Network and Computer Vision. Land, 13(11), 1796.

PRS_POV.name: Poverty Dimension
PRS_POV.definition: A socioeconomic subdimension tracking indicators of indigence, such as low-income distribution, welfare dependency ratios, or the prevalence of discussions and reports regarding financial hardship within the population.

supporting_papers.citation: Meng, Y., Xing, H., Yuan, Y., Wong, M. S., & Fan, K. (2020). Sensing urban poverty: From the perspective of human perception-based greenery and open-space landscapes. Computers, Environment and Urban Systems, 84, 101544.

PRS_STY.name: Presentation Style
PRS_STY.definition: This dimension categorizes the rhetorical or communicative mode employed in the media content. It distinguishes between different approaches to delivering information, such as rational-legal argumentation, emotional storytelling, aggressive confrontation, or bureaucratic reporting. In political communication analysis, this variable helps researchers understand whether an actor is relying on factual logic or affective appeals to persuade the audience.

PRS_UNSPECIFIED.name: Presentation Unspecified
PRS_UNSPECIFIED.definition: This category is assigned to data points where the specific subdimension could not be determined, the content was ambiguous, or the relevant attributes were missing from the source material. It serves as a residual category to ensure dataset completeness without forcing unclear data into substantive categories, thereby maintaining the methodological integrity of the coding scheme.

supporting_papers.citation: Li, X., Ratti, C., & Seiferling, I. (2017). Mapping Urban Landscapes Along Streets Using Google Street View. Lecture Notes in Geoinformation and Cartography, 341–356.

PRS_CRI.name: Presentation Crisis
PRS_CRI.definition: This thematic dimension identifies content that explicitly discusses emergency situations, existential threats, or urgent societal disruptions. It is often used in political frame analysis to tag messages related to health crises (e.g., pandemics), security threats, or environmental disasters, analyzing how actors construct narratives of urgency to justify specific interventions or mobilize public sentiment.

supporting_papers.citation: Amiruzzaman, M., Zhao, Y., Amiruzzaman, S., Karpinski, A. C., & Wu, T. H. (2023). An AI-based framework for studying visual diversity of urban neighborhoods and its relationship with socio-demographic variables. Journal of Computational Social Science, 6(1), 315–337.

PRS_RST.name: Presentation Restriction
PRS_RST.definition: This code refers to content focusing on regulatory limitations, behavioral constraints, or lockdowns imposed on the public. Frequently used in datasets analyzing communication during the COVID-19 pandemic or security emergencies, it tracks mentions of curfews, social distancing mandates, border closures, and the suspension of civil liberties, allowing researchers to gauge the salience of restrictive measures in public discourse.

supporting_papers.citation: Zeng, L., Lindberg, F., Zhang, X., Pan, H., & Lu, J. (2023). Road surface temperature evaluated with streetview-derived parameters in a hot and humid megacity. Urban Climate, 51, 101585.

PRS_DPS.name: Presentation Depression / Despair
PRS_DPS.definition: A sentiment dimension quantifying negative emotional affect characterized by sadness, hopelessness, gloom, or defeat. This code tracks the usage of depressive language or imagery (e.g., dark colors, crying figures, tragic narratives) to identify frames of mourning, failure, or victimization within political or social media discourse.

supporting_papers.citation: Kang, Y., Zhang, F., Gao, S., Lin, H., & Liu, Y. (2020). A review of urban physical environment sensing using street view imagery in public health studies. Annals of GIS, 26(3), 261–275.

PRS_VAL.name: Presentation Value
PRS_VAL.definition: This dimension captures references to normative principles, moral beliefs, and ideological commitments. Unlike factual or economic arguments, 'Value' codes for appeals to abstract concepts such as freedom, solidarity, tradition, justice, or democracy. It allows researchers to identify when communicative actors shift from pragmatic governance discussions to moralizing or ideological framing.

supporting_papers.citation: An, S., Jang, H., Kim, H., Song, Y., & Ahn, K. (2023). Assessment of street-level greenness and its association with housing prices in a metropolitan area. Scientific Reports, 13(1).

PRS_ECO.name: Presentation Economic
PRS_ECO.definition: A thematic dimension flagging content related to financial systems, markets, employment, fiscal policy, or monetary value. This code is used to track the salience of economic framing in public discourse, identifying when actors prioritize material concerns (e.g., inflation, jobs, GDP) over social, cultural, or health-related issues.

supporting_papers.citation: Amiruzzaman, M., Zhao, Y., Amiruzzaman, S., Karpinski, A. C., & Wu, T. H. (2023). An AI-based framework for studying visual diversity of urban neighborhoods and its relationship with socio-demographic variables. Journal of Computational Social Science, 6(1), 315–337.

PRS_VIS_DOM.name: Presentation Visual Dominance
PRS_VIS_DOM.definition: This variable measures the relative weight or prominence of visual components compared to textual elements within a post. It assesses whether the image is the primary driver of meaning (high visual dominance) or merely decorative accompaniment to text. This is critical in social media analysis for understanding the shift toward 'image-byte' politics and visual storytelling.

supporting_papers.citation: Stancato, G. (2024). The Visual Greenery Field: Representing the Urban Green Visual Continuum with Street View Image Analysis. Sustainability, 16(21), 9512.

PRS_PM_CON.name: Presentation Participatory Media Connectivity
PRS_PM_CON.definition: This dimension measures the presence of digital affordances designed to foster user interaction and network connectivity. It codes for elements such as explicit calls to action (e.g., 'Share this,' 'Tag a friend'), the use of hashtags, hyperlinks to external resources, or questions addressed to the audience. It reflects the degree to which the content acts as a bridge for mobilization rather than a one-way broadcast.

supporting_papers.citation: O'Regan, A. C., Byrne, R., Hellebust, S., & Nyhan, M. M. (2022). Associations between Google Street View-derived urban greenspace metrics and air pollution measured using a distributed sensor network. Sustainable Cities and Society, 87, 104221.

PRS_POP.name: Population Dimensions
PRS_POP.definition: A subdimension of predictors related to demographic characteristics and human presence within a studied environment. This category encompasses variables such as population density, demographic composition (age, gender), human mobility flows, and the intensity of human activity in urban or digital spaces.

supporting_papers.citation: Amiruzzaman, M., Zhao, Y., Amiruzzaman, S., Karpinski, A. C., & Wu, T. H. (2023). An AI-based framework for studying visual diversity of urban neighborhoods and its relationship with socio-demographic variables. Journal of Computational Social Science, 6(1), 315–337.

PRS_REG.name: Regional and Regulatory Factors
PRS_REG.definition: A subdimension referring to the geographic, administrative, or policy-based context of the study. This includes variables related to specific regions, zoning laws, urban planning regulations, and administrative boundaries that influence the primary subject of analysis, distinguishing local dynamics from macro-level governance.

supporting_papers.citation: Chan, T.-C., Lee, P.-H., Lee, Y.-T., & Tang, J.-H. (2024). Exploring the spatial association between the distribution of temperature and urban morphology with green view index. PLOS ONE, 19(5), e0301921.

PRS_VIS.name: Visual Attributes
PRS_VIS.definition: A subdimension focusing on the observable physical characteristics and aesthetic qualities of an environment or object. This includes the analysis of colors, textures, lighting, shapes, and structural designs, often derived from image data (e.g., Street View Imagery) to assess how visual composition affects human perception.

supporting_papers.citation: Chen, Y., Zhang, Q., Deng, Z., Fan, X., Xu, Z., Kang, X., Pan, K., & Guo, Z. (2022). Research on Green View Index of Urban Roads Based on Street View Image Recognition: A Case Study of Changsha Downtown Areas. Sustainability, 14(23), 16063.
Hou, S., Yu, Y., Jung, T., & Han, X. (2025). How to Coordinate Urban Ecological Networks and Street Green Space Construction? Insights from a Multi-Scale Perspective. Land, 14(1), 26.

Jing, X., Li, Z., Chen, H., & Zhang, C. (2024). "Is What We See Always Real?" A Comparative Study of Two-Dimensional and Three-Dimensional Urban Green Spaces: The Case of Shenzhen's Central District. Forests, 15(6), 983.

PRS_NA.name: Not Applicable
PRS_NA.definition: A classification used when specific subdimensions of predictors or pressures are irrelevant, missing, or cannot be categorized into the established coding scheme for a particular entry or dataset.

supporting_papers.citation: Jing, F., Liu, L., Zhou, S., Song, J., Wang, L., Zhou, H., Wang, Y., & Ma, R. (2021). Assessing the Impact of Street-View Greenery on Fear of Neighborhood Crime in Guangzhou, China. International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health, 18(1), 311.

Zhu, J., Li, B., Ouyang, H., Wang, Y., & Bai, Z. (2024). Understanding Urban Residents' Walking Exercise Preferences: An Empirical Study Using Street View Images and Trajectory Data. Buildings, 14(2), 549.

Chen, J., Zhou, C., & Li, F. (2020). Quantifying the green view indicator for assessing urban greening quality: An analysis based on Internet-crawling street view data. Ecological Indicators, 113, 106192.

Zhu, J., Qiu, L., Su, Y., Guo, Q., Hu, T., Bao, H., Luo, J., Wu, S., Xu, Q., Wang, Z., & Pan, Y. (2022). Disentangling the effects of the surrounding environment on street-side greenery: Evidence from Hangzhou. Ecological Indicators, 143, 109153.

PRS_SOC_ECO.name: Socio-Economic Factors
PRS_SOC_ECO.definition: A subdimension encompassing variables related to social and economic status. This includes indicators such as income levels, housing prices, employment rates, education levels, and social class, which serve as critical predictors for urban development, public health, and behavioral outcomes.

supporting_papers.citation: Wang, R., Feng, Z., Pearce, J., Yao, Y., Li, X., & Liu, Y. (2021). The distribution of greenspace quantity and quality and their association with neighbourhood socioeconomic conditions in Guangzhou, China: A new approach using deep learning method and street view images. Sustainable Cities and Society, 66, 102664.

PRS_GRN.name: Green Infrastructure
PRS_GRN.definition: A subdimension relating to natural elements within an environment. This includes the presence, density, and quality of vegetation, parks, tree canopies, and open green spaces, which are analyzed for their impact on environmental quality, psychological well-being, and urban aesthetics.

supporting_papers.citation: Tong, Z., & Gong, C. (2022). Integrating Characteristics of Vertical Viewing Angle into Quantitative Analysis of Street View Photos. 2022 29th International Conference on Geoinformatics, 1–6.

PRS_ACC.name: Performance - Accessibility
PRS_ACC.definition: Measures the ease with which individuals can reach, enter, and utilize a space or service. This performance metric encompasses physical connectivity (e.g., proximity to transit, ramp availability), visual navigation, and inclusivity. In urban planning, it evaluates the network integration of a location and the absence of barriers that might exclude specific demographic groups, ensuring equitable usage for the elderly, disabled, or economically disadvantaged.

supporting_papers.citation: Sánchez, I. A. V., & Labib, S. M. (2024). Accessing eye-level greenness visibility from open-source street view images: A methodological development and implementation in multi-city and multi-country contexts. Sustainable Cities and Society, 103, 105262.

PRS_AFF_NEG.name: Performance - Affective Negative Perception
PRS_AFF_NEG.definition: A metric representing the degree to which a specific environment elicits negative emotional responses from observers or users. In environmental psychology and urban analysis, this performance indicator captures sentiments such as fear, anxiety, or distress associated with visual or physical features of the built environment. It is often quantified through surveys or computer vision algorithms that analyze semantic content and facial expressions to determine the adverse emotional impact of a space.

supporting_papers.citation: Liu, Y., Xiao, T., Liu, Y., Yao, Y., & Wang, R. (2021). Natural outdoor environments and subjective well-being in Guangzhou, China: Comparing different measures of access. Urban Forestry & Urban Greening, 59, 127027.

PRS_AFF_POS.name: Performance - Affective Positive Perception
PRS_AFF_POS.definition: Refers to the extent to which an environment triggers positive emotional responses, such as happiness, joy, or serenity. As the counterpart to affective negative perception, this metric evaluates the success of urban design in fostering psychological well-being. It is typically measured through sentiment analysis of user feedback or facial expressions, highlighting spaces that successfully create a sense of place and emotional attachment.

supporting_papers.citation: Xin, B., Zhu, C., Geng, J., & Liu, Y. (2024). Emotional Perceptions of Thermal Comfort for People Exposed to Green Spaces Characterized Using Streetscapes in Urban Parks. Land, 13(9), 1515.

PRS_ATT.name: Visual Attention / Saliency
PRS_ATT.definition: A metric derived from cognitive science and computer vision (saliency mapping) that predicts which parts of an urban scene will instinctively grab a human observer's gaze. It evaluates the visual prominence of architectural features based on contrast, color, and orientation.

supporting_papers.citation: Qiu, Y., Pan, H., Kalantari, Z., Giusti, M., & Che, S. (2023). The natural focus: Combining deep learning and eye-tracking to understand public perceptions of urban ecosystem aesthetics. Ecological Indicators, 156, 111181.

PRS_BEA_VIS.name: Visual Beauty Score
PRS_BEA_VIS.definition: A perceptual metric quantifying the aesthetic appeal of an urban scene. Often derived from crowdsourced pairwise comparisons (e.g., 'Place Pulse') or computer vision models trained on human preferences, it rates the scenic value and visual attractiveness of streetscapes.

supporting_papers.citation: Liang, X., Zhao, T., & Biljecki, F. (2023). Revealing spatio-temporal evolution of urban visual environments with street view imagery. Landscape and Urban Planning, 237, 104802.

PRS_BEH.name: Behavioral Outcomes

supporting_papers.citation: Gao, F., Li, S., Tan, Z., Zhang, X., Lai, Z., & Tan, Z. (2021). How Is Urban Greenness Spatially Associated with Dockless Bike Sharing Usage on Weekdays, Weekends, and Holidays? ISPRS International Journal of Geo-Information, 10(4), 238.

PRS_BEH.first_confirmed_by: Chen, Y., Chen, Y., Tu, W., & Zeng, X. (2020). Is eye-level greening associated with the use of dockless shared bicycles? Urban Forestry & Urban Greening, 51, 126690.

PRS_CYC.name: Cyclability Score
PRS_CYC.definition: A suitability index measuring how conducive a route or area is to bicycle travel. It incorporates factors such as dedicated bike lane infrastructure, traffic speed, road surface quality, slope (topography), and safety connectivity to determine the 'bikeability' of the urban fabric.

supporting_papers.citation: Kang, Y., Zhang, F., Gao, S., Lin, H., & Liu, Y. (2020). A review of urban physical environment sensing using street view imagery in public health studies. Annals of GIS, 26(3), 261–275.

supporting_papers.paper_file: Luo P, Yu B, Li P and Liang P (2022)
supporting_papers.citation: Luo, P., Yu, B., Li, P., & Liang, P. (2022). Spatially varying impacts of the built environment on physical activity from a human-scale view: Using street view data. Frontiers in Environmental Science, 10.

PRS_EAP.name: Economic Activity and Performance
PRS_EAP.definition: An index measuring the economic vitality of a region, often calculated using the Economically Active Population (EAP), GDP per capita, productivity rates, and employment density to gauge financial health and labor market strength.

supporting_papers.citation: Qiu, Y., Pan, H., Kalantari, Z., Giusti, M., & Che, S. (2023). The natural focus: Combining deep learning and eye-tracking to understand public perceptions of urban ecosystem aesthetics. Ecological Indicators, 156, 111181.

PRS_EXE_PRE.name: Executive Presence
PRS_EXE_PRE.definition: A measure of a city's economic command and control capabilities, typically assessed by the concentration of multinational corporation headquarters, high-level business services, and executive decision-making functions within the urban area.

supporting_papers.citation: Zhu, J., Li, B., Ouyang, H., Wang, Y., & Bai, Z. (2024). Understanding Urban Residents' Walking Exercise Preferences: An Empirical Study Using Street View Images and Trajectory Data. Buildings, 14(2), 549.

PRS_HDF.name: Performance - Hardscape Features
PRS_HDF.definition: Refers to the performance or prevalence of man-made, non-living hardscape elements within a public space. This metric evaluates the impact of paved areas, walls, street furniture, and concrete structures on the environment. Assessing this variable helps determine the balance between grey infrastructure and green elements, influencing factors such as surface temperature (heat island effect), water permeability, and the aesthetic utility of an urban environment.

supporting_papers.citation: Wu, R., Fang, X., Brown, R., Liu, S., & Zhao, H. (2023). Establishing a link between complex courtyard spaces and thermal comfort: A major advancement in evidence-based design. Building and Environment, 245, 110852.

PRS_HPR.name: Performance - Health Promotion Resources
PRS_HPR.definition: Measures the capacity of a built environment to actively foster healthy behaviors and lifestyles through specific resources. Distinct from passive health benefits, this metric focuses on the presence and quality of active design features—such as exercise stations, sports courts, and jogging tracks—that facilitate physical exertion and social interaction. It evaluates the environment's effectiveness in engaging the community in health-enhancing activities.

PRS_LIV.name: Livability
PRS_LIV.definition: A comprehensive indicator assessing the quality of life in a city, incorporating factors such as safety, housing affordability, healthcare access, educational opportunities, culture, and overall residential satisfaction.

supporting_papers.citation: Liang, X., Zhao, T., & Biljecki, F. (2023). Revealing spatio-temporal evolution of urban visual environments with street view imagery. Landscape and Urban Planning, 237, 104802.

Shen, Q., Zeng, W., Ye, Y., Arisona, S. M., Schubiger, S., Burkhard, R., & Qu, H. (2018). StreetVizor: Visual Exploration of Human-Scale Urban Forms Based on Street Views. IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics, 24(1), 1004–1013.

PRS_NAV.name: Navigation and Accessibility
PRS_NAV.definition: A performance metric evaluating the efficiency and connectivity of a city's transportation networks, including public transit coverage, traffic congestion levels, infrastructure quality, and the overall ease of mobility for residents and commuters.

PRS_PSY_FEE.name: Performance - Psychological Feeling
PRS_PSY_FEE.definition: Represents the overall subjective psychological state or emotional impact induced by an environment on an individual. This metric evaluates how a space influences mental well-being, encompassing intangible qualities such as comfort, relaxation, and stress levels. It measures the restorative potential of a setting, analyzing how design elements contribute to the user's internal cognitive and emotional processing of the space.

PRS_RUN.name: Performance - Runnability
PRS_RUN.definition: Evaluates the suitability and attractiveness of an environment specifically for running or jogging activities. This performance metric considers factors such as path continuity, surface shock absorption, separation from vehicular traffic, and air quality. It is used in urban design to identify corridors that support high-intensity cardiovascular exercise, differentiating them from spaces designed merely for casual leisure or static recreation.

supporting_papers.paper_file: Luo P, Yu B, Li P and Liang P (2022)
supporting_papers.citation: Luo, P., Yu, B., Li, P., & Liang, P. (2022). Spatially varying impacts of the built environment on physical activity from a human-scale view: Using street view data. Frontiers in Environmental Science, 10.

PRS_SAD.name: Performance - Sadness Perception
PRS_SAD.definition: A specific sub-metric of affective performance that quantifies the evocation of sadness, melancholy, or gloom by an environment. In visual sentiment analysis, this variable identifies specific features—such as urban decay, lack of color, poor lighting, or isolation—that contribute to a depressive atmosphere. It is used to identify areas of urban blight or neglect that may require intervention to improve the community's emotional health.

supporting_papers.citation: Xin, B., Zhu, C., Geng, J., & Liu, Y. (2024). Emotional Perceptions of Thermal Comfort for People Exposed to Green Spaces Characterized Using Streetscapes in Urban Parks. Land, 13(9), 1515.

PRS_SAF_VIS.name: Performance - Visual Safety
PRS_SAF_VIS.definition: Measures the perception of safety derived specifically from visual cues within an environment. This performance indicator assesses how elements like lighting brightness, sightlines, maintenance levels, and the presence of surveillance (natural or technological) influence a user's sense of security. It is widely used in urban studies to determine the visual permeability and order that contribute to Crime Prevention Through Environmental Design (CPTED) standards.

supporting_papers.citation: Liang, X., Zhao, T., & Biljecki, F. (2023). Revealing spatio-temporal evolution of urban visual environments with street view imagery. Landscape and Urban Planning, 237, 104802.

Zhang, Y., Li, S., Dong, R., Deng, H., Fu, X., Wang, C., Yu, T., Jia, T., & Zhao, J. (2021). Quantifying physical and psychological perceptions of urban scenes using deep learning. Land Use Policy, 111, 105762.

PRS_SAT.name: Performance - Satisfaction
PRS_SAT.definition: Quantifies the level of gratification or contentment expressed by users regarding a specific space or facility. In post-occupancy evaluations, this variable aggregates user feedback on various attributes—such as aesthetics, functionality, cleanliness, and amenities—to determine if the environment meets the expectations and needs of the population it serves. It serves as a high-level indicator of the overall success of an urban design project.

supporting_papers.citation: Liu, Y., Xiao, T., Liu, Y., Yao, Y., & Wang, R. (2021). Natural outdoor environments and subjective well-being in Guangzhou, China: Comparing different measures of access. Urban Forestry & Urban Greening, 59, 127027.

PRS_URB_QUA.name: Urban Quality Index
PRS_URB_QUA.definition: A multidimensional assessment of the built environment's condition and appeal. This aggregate metric evaluates both objective physical attributes (maintenance, infrastructure) and subjective perceptual qualities (sense of place, enclosure, and complexity) to determine the overall livability of a space.

supporting_papers.citation: Qi, S. (2024). Utilizing Semantic Segmentation to Analyse Google Street View Imagery for Health-Oriented Urban Planning. Geoforum Perspektiv, 44, 39-46.

PRS_WEA_VIS.name: Performance - Perceived Wealth Visual
PRS_WEA_VIS.definition: Measures the visual indicators of economic prosperity or affluence within a specific environment. Using features such as building maintenance, material quality, architectural style, and street cleanliness, this metric estimates the socioeconomic status of a neighborhood based solely on its visual appearance. In urban studies, it often serves as a proxy for analyzing investment patterns and resource allocation disparities across different districts.

supporting_papers.citation: Zhang, Y., Li, S., Dong, R., Deng, H., Fu, X., Wang, C., Yu, T., Jia, T., & Zhao, J. (2021). Quantifying physical and psychological perceptions of urban scenes using deep learning. Land Use Policy, 111, 105762.

PRS_WLK.name: Walkability Score
PRS_WLK.definition: A performance metric assessing the degree to which an environment is friendly to walking. It synthesizes variables such as residential density, intersection connectivity, land-use mix, and safety infrastructure to evaluate the comfort, convenience, and efficiency of pedestrian movement.

supporting_papers.citation: Kang, Y., Zhang, F., Gao, S., Lin, H., & Liu, Y. (2020). A review of urban physical environment sensing using street view imagery in public health studies. Annals of GIS, 26(3), 261–275.

Zhu, J., Li, B., Ouyang, H., Wang, Y., & Bai, Z. (2024). Understanding Urban Residents' Walking Exercise Preferences: An Empirical Study Using Street View Images and Trajectory Data. Buildings, 14(2), 549.

PRS_WLK_VIS.name: Performance - Visual Walkability
PRS_WLK_VIS.definition: Assesses the visual qualities of an environment that explicitly encourage or discourage walking behaviors. This metric analyzes streetscape imagery for features such as sidewalk width, shading, aesthetic interest, and complexity. It connects visual perception with active transportation behavior, determining how inviting, comfortable, and interesting a specific route appears to pedestrians, thereby influencing their decision to walk rather than drive.

supporting_papers.citation: Wang, M., Haworth, J., Chen, H., Liu, Y., & Shi, Z. (2024). Investigating the potential of crowdsourced street-level imagery in understanding the spatiotemporal dynamics of cities: A case study of walkability in Inner London. Cities, 153, 105243.

OUT_OBJ.name: Objective Measurement
OUT_OBJ.definition: OUT_OBJ refers to data derived from quantitative, instrument-based assessments rather than self-reported or subjective evaluations. This category encompasses environmental metrics obtained through calibrated scientific tools, such as air quality sensors, noise level meters, or spatial analysis via GIS. By relying on reproducible physical measurements, this outcome ensures empirical precision and minimizes observer bias, providing a standardized baseline for evaluating environmental conditions and their direct physical impact on urban settings.

supporting_papers.citation: An, S., Jang, H., Kim, H., Song, Y., & Ahn, K. (2023). Assessment of street-level greenness and its association with housing prices in a metropolitan area. Scientific Reports, 13(1).

OUT_SUB.name: Subjective Rating
OUT_SUB.definition: Subjective rating refers to the traditional, human-centric evaluation of 'visual perception' and 'perceived safety.' The text notes that visual perception has historically been treated as an abstract concept evaluated through methods like the U.S. National Scenic Byways Program, which relies on qualities like memorability and uniqueness. The study contrasts these self-reported or manual perceptions with automated extraction techniques to overcome data shortages.

OUT_BEH.name: Behavioral Observation
OUT_BEH.definition: OUT_BEH involves the systematic recording of human actions, movements, and usage patterns within a specific setting. This data collection method relies on direct observation, mapping, or video analysis to document physical activities, such as walking speeds, dwell times, or social interactions. By capturing actual conduct rather than reported intent, this variable provides ecological validity, revealing how individuals authentically occupy and navigate space in real-time response to environmental design and ambient conditions.

OUT_PHY.name: Physiological
OUT_PHY.definition: OUT_PHY pertains to the measurement of involuntary biological responses in the human body, serving as biomarkers for health status, stress, or arousal. Common metrics include heart rate variability (HRV), cortisol levels, skin conductance, and electroencephalography (EEG) readings. These objective indicators provide critical insights into the immediate, often unconscious, impacts of environmental stimuli on human physiology, allowing researchers to quantify the restorative or stress-inducing effects of specific settings with high biological precision.

OUT_STA.name: Statistical Outcomes
OUT_STA.definition: A type of outcome focused on quantitative indicators and statistical relationships. This category includes results derived from regression analyses, correlations, and descriptive statistics that establish numerical patterns between predictors and dependent variables without necessarily inferring psychological or algorithmic performance.

OUT_PSY.name: Psychological Outcomes
OUT_PSY.definition: A type of outcome pertaining to mental states, cognitive processes, and emotional responses. This includes measurements of stress, happiness, perceived safety, aesthetic preference, and mental well-being, often assessed through surveys or sentiment analysis in response to environmental or social stimuli.

supporting_papers.citation: Verma, D., Jana, A., & Ramamritham, K. (2018). Quantifying Urban Surroundings Using Deep Learning Techniques: A New Proposal. Urban Science, 2(3), 78.

OUT_ALG.name: Algorithmic Performance
OUT_ALG.definition: A type of outcome evaluating the technical success of computational models. This includes metrics such as prediction accuracy, precision, recall, F1 scores, and processing efficiency, typically used to validate machine learning models or automated analysis tools.

OUT_NA.name: Not Applicable
OUT_NA.definition: Indicates that the outcome type is not applicable or not reported for this evidence record.

THR_NA.name: Not Applicable
THR_NA.definition: THR_NA indicates that a specific study or variable analysis is not explicitly grounded in a pre-defined theoretical framework or conceptual model. This classification is often applied to exploratory research, data mining exercises, or descriptive studies where the primary goal is to observe phenomena or identify patterns without testing a specific hypothesis derived from theory. It suggests that the relationship is being examined for empirical discovery rather than for the validation of existing theoretical constructs.

THR_BWT.name: Broken Windows Theory

supporting_papers.citation: Jing, F., Liu, L., Zhou, S., Song, J., Wang, L., Zhou, H., Wang, Y., & Ma, R. (2021). Assessing the Impact of Street-View Greenery on Fear of Neighborhood Crime in Guangzhou, China. International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health, 18(1), 311.

THR_BWT.definition: Criminological theory stating that visible signs of crime, anti-social behavior, and civil disorder create an urban environment that encourages further crime and disorder.
THR_BWT.first_confirmed_by: Jing, F.; Liu, L.; Zhou, S.; Song, J.; Wang, L.; Zhou, H.; Wang, Y.; Ma, R. Assessing the Impact of Street-View Greenery on Fear of Neighborhood Crime in Guangzhou, China. Int. J. Environ. Res. Public Health 2021, 18, 311.

THR_SOC_ECO.name: Social-Ecological Theory
THR_SOC_ECO.definition: A theory suggesting that environmental factors in cities influence the likelihood of people being physically active.

THR_PSD.name: Perceived Sensory Dimensions

THR_PSD.definition: A framework describing eight perceived dimensions of green spaces: Natural, Cultural, Cohesive, Diverse, Sheltered, Open, Serene, Social.
THR_PSD.first_confirmed_by: Zhang, X., Lin, E. S., Tan, P. Y., Qi, J., & Waykool, R. (2023). Assessment of visual landscape quality of urban green spaces using image-based metrics derived from perceived sensory dimensions. Environmental Impact Assessment Review, 102, 107200.

THR_UNSPECIFIED.name: Unspecified Theory
THR_UNSPECIFIED.definition: A code applied when the theoretical framework guiding a study is not explicitly stated, or when the research is inductive and data-driven rather than grounded in a pre-existing specific academic theory.

supporting_papers.citation: Li, X., Ratti, C., & Seiferling, I. (2017). Mapping Urban Landscapes Along Streets Using Google Street View. Lecture Notes in Geoinformation and Cartography, 341–356.

THR_EPY.name: Entropy Theory
THR_EPY.definition: A theoretical framework derived from information theory and thermodynamics, applied to measure disorder, diversity, or complexity within a system. In urban contexts (Shannon Entropy), it is often used to quantify the mix of land uses, the diversity of points of interest, or the equilibrium of spatial systems.

THR_XXX.name: Miscellaneous / Other Theories
THR_XXX.definition: A catch-all category for theoretical frameworks that do not fit into the standard classification list. This code is used for niche, emerging, or less frequently cited theories that appear in the dataset but do not warrant a dedicated category.

THR_HPM.name: Hedonic Price Model
THR_HPM.definition: An econometric method used to estimate the monetary value of a product's characteristics. In real estate and urban planning, it decomposes the price of a property into values associated with specific attributes, such as structural features, neighborhood amenities, and environmental quality.

THR_UNK.name: Unknown Theory
THR_UNK.definition: A coding classification used when the theoretical framework of a study is not explicitly stated by the authors or cannot be definitively categorized into an existing theoretical model.

THR_Hedonic.name: Hedonic Theory
THR_Hedonic.definition: The underlying economic theory proposing that goods are viewed as a bundle of attributes, and consumers derive utility from these individual attributes rather than the good itself. This forms the theoretical basis for the Hedonic Price Model.

REL_COR.name: Correlation
REL_COR.definition: REL_COR describes a statistical relationship where two or more variables fluctuate together, indicating an association without necessarily implying a cause-and-effect mechanic. This category encompasses analyses such as Pearson or Spearman correlation coefficients, highlighting the strength and direction of the linear relationship between environmental factors and outcomes. While valuable for identifying patterns, a correlational finding suggests that changes in one variable are associated with changes in another, but does not rule out confounding factors.

REL_REG.name: Regression
REL_REG.definition: REL_REG refers to statistical analyses used to estimate the strength and character of the relationship between a dependent variable and one or more independent variables. Unlike simple correlation, regression models—such as linear or logistic regression—aim to predict outcomes and isolate the specific contribution of individual predictors while controlling for confounding factors. This approach allows researchers to quantify the magnitude of change in an outcome variable that results from a unit change in an environmental predictor.

supporting_papers.citation: Li, X., Liu, Q., Liu, X., & Ren, Y. (2025). Greener is healthier: Unraveling the distinction of health impacts of urban green indicators in Wuhan, China. Sustainable Cities and Society, 125, 106318.

REL_MED.name: Mediation
REL_MED.definition: REL_MED identifies a mechanism through which an independent variable influences a dependent variable, explaining the 'how' or 'why' of a relationship. In a mediation model, the intervention or exposure affects a mediator variable, which in turn affects the outcome. This analysis is crucial for understanding causal pathways, such as how green space (independent variable) reduces stress (outcome) specifically through the mechanism of noise reduction (mediator), rather than through a direct, unexplained link.

REL_MOD.name: Moderation
REL_MOD.definition: REL_MOD describes a relationship where a third variable affects the strength or direction of the association between an independent and a dependent variable. A moderator specifies 'when' or 'for whom' an effect occurs. For example, the benefit of a park on mental health might be moderated by age, meaning the relationship changes depending on the demographic group. This analysis highlights interaction effects, revealing boundary conditions and nuances in how environmental factors impact different populations.

REL_THR.name: Threshold
REL_THR.definition: REL_THR identifies a non-linear relationship where an effect only manifests, accelerates, or ceases once a specific level of the independent variable is reached. This 'tipping point' suggests that below or above a certain concentration or quantity of an environmental factor (such as noise decibels or green space density), the outcome remains stable, but crossing the threshold triggers a distinct change. Understanding these critical points is vital for establishing minimum standards or maximum limits in policy.

REL_DOR.name: Dose-Response
REL_DOR.definition: REL_DOR describes a relationship where the magnitude of the outcome changes in a consistent gradient relative to the quantity or intensity of the exposure. Borrowed from toxicology and epidemiology, this concept tests whether greater exposure to an environmental factor (the 'dose') leads to a proportionally greater or lesser effect (the 'response'). Establishing a dose-response curve strengthens causal inference, helping researchers determine optimal levels of intervention needed to achieve measurable results.

REL_DES.name: Descriptive Relationship
REL_DES.definition: A relationship between variables that is characterized qualitatively or through summary statistics, rather than through inferential statistical modeling. It describes the state or nature of the data without necessarily establishing causality or statistical significance.

REL_VSH.name: V-shaped Relationship
REL_VSH.definition: A non-linear relationship where the dependent variable decreases to a minimum point and then increases (or vice versa) as the independent variable changes. In spatial analysis, this may describe effects that are negative at short distances but positive at longer distances.

REL_PRE.name: Predictive Relationship
REL_PRE.definition: A statistical association established for the purpose of forecasting future outcomes or trends. This category generally refers to models designed to predict the value of a dependent variable based on known values of independent variables.

REL_LOG.definition: A relationship following a logistic function (S-curve), characterized by slow initial growth, followed by exponential growth, and eventually leveling off as it approaches a carrying capacity or maximum limit.

REL_NS.definition: A statistical result indicating that the relationship between the tested variables is not strong enough to reject the null hypothesis (typically p > 0.05). It implies that observed effects may be due to chance.

REL_NLN.name: Non-linear Relationship
REL_NLN.definition: A statistical association between two variables in which the rate of change is not constant. DIR_NA.name: Not Applicable
DIR_NA.definition: DIR_NA denotes scenarios where the concept of directionality—positive, negative, or causal flow—is irrelevant or undefined. This classification is typically used for descriptive statistics, nominal categorizations, or qualitative assessments where variables are not ordinal or numeric. It acknowledges that for certain study designs or data types, analyzing an increase or decrease is logically incoherent. Consequently, this code signals that the focus is on the existence or classification of a phenomenon rather than its trajectory.

DIR_NLN.name: Non-linear Direction
DIR_NLN.definition: Refers to the directional component of a non-linear relationship. It signifies that the direction of the effect may change depending on the level of exposure (e.g., a relationship that is positive at low levels but becomes negative at high levels), requiring complex interpretation rather than a simple positive/negative binary.

DIR_NS.name: Not Significant
DIR_NS.definition: A statistical result indicating that the observed association between variables is likely due to chance. Technically, the p-value exceeds the chosen threshold (typically 0.05), meaning there is insufficient evidence to reject the null hypothesis and conclude that a true effect exists in the population.

SIG_01.name: p < 0.01
SIG_01.definition: Indicates a highly statistically significant result where the probability of observing the data, given that the null hypothesis is true, is less than 1%. This threshold suggests strong evidence against the null hypothesis, offering a higher level of confidence than the standard 0.05 level. In scientific research, this rigorous cutoff reduces the likelihood of Type I errors (false positives), implying that the observed effects are very unlikely to be the product of random chance, though it does not inherently confirm the practical magnitude of the effect.

SIG_05.name: p < 0.05
SIG_05.definition: Represents the standard threshold for statistical significance in most scientific disciplines. It indicates that there is less than a 5% probability of obtaining the observed results, or more extreme results, if the null hypothesis were true. While this cutoff implies that the effect is likely non-random, researchers must interpret it alongside effect sizes and confidence intervals. It serves as a conventional boundary for rejecting the null hypothesis, balancing the risks of Type I (false positive) and Type II (false negative) errors in hypothesis testing.

SIG_NS.name: Not Significant
SIG_NS.definition: Denotes that the statistical analysis did not yield evidence strong enough to reject the null hypothesis, usually because the p-value exceeds the designated alpha level (typically 0.05). This result implies that any observed differences or associations in the data could plausibly be attributed to random sampling variability. However, a non-significant result does not prove the null hypothesis is true or that an effect is absent; it may also reflect insufficient statistical power, small sample sizes, or high measurement error within the study design.

SIG_005.name: Significance Level (p < 0.05)
SIG_005.definition: Represents the standard threshold for statistical significance in scientific research. A value of '005' indicates a p-value less than 0.05, implying there is less than a 5% probability that the observed results occurred by random chance, assuming the null hypothesis is true.

TST_SPR.name: Spearman Correlation
TST_SPR.definition: A non-parametric measure of rank correlation used to assess the strength and direction of a monotonic relationship between two variables. Unlike Pearson correlation, Spearman's rho does not assume a linear relationship or a normal distribution of the data. Instead, it relies on the ranked values of the variables, making it robust against outliers and suitable for ordinal data or continuous data that violates parametric assumptions. Values range from -1 to +1, indicating perfect negative or positive monotonic associations, respectively.
TST_SPR.first_confirmed_by: Zhao, X., & Lin, G. (2024). Research on the Perception Evaluation of Urban Green Spaces Using Panoramic Images and Deep Learning: A Case Study of Zhujiang Park in Guangzhou. Landscape Architecture Frontiers, 12(6), 007-024.

TST_REG.name: Regression
TST_REG.definition: A statistical method used to model and analyze the relationship between a dependent variable and one or more independent variables. This category encompasses linear regression, which assumes a straight-line relationship, and multiple regression, which controls for confounding factors. It allows researchers to estimate the effect size of predictors, forecast outcomes, and infer causal associations under specific assumptions. Regression analysis is fundamental for quantification, helping to determine how much the response variable changes when an explanatory variable is varied while holding others constant.

TST_ANV.name: ANOVA
TST_ANV.definition: Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) is a statistical technique used to compare the means of three or more independent groups to determine if at least one group mean is statistically different from the others. By partitioning the total observed variance into variation between groups and variation within groups, ANOVA produces an F-statistic to test the null hypothesis of equal means. It is widely used in experimental designs to analyze the impact of categorical independent variables (factors) on a continuous dependent variable.

TST_SEM.name: Structural Equation Modeling
TST_SEM.definition: Structural Equation Modeling (SEM) is a comprehensive multivariate statistical analysis technique that combines factor analysis and multiple regression. It allows researchers to test complex theoretical models involving both observable and latent (unobservable) variables. SEM explicitly accounts for measurement error and examines structural relationships between variables simultaneously. This approach is particularly useful for theory confirmation, assessing mediation effects, and analyzing complex causal networks where variables can act as both predictors and outcomes within a unified model structure.

supporting_papers.citation: Chen, M., Cai, Y., Guo, S., Sun, R., Song, Y., & Shen, X. (2024). Evaluating implied urban nature vitality in San Francisco: An interdisciplinary approach combining census data, street view images, and social media analysis. Urban Forestry & Urban Greening, 95, 128289.

TST_SEM.first_confirmed_by: Chen, M., Cai, Y., Guo, S., Sun, R., Song, Y., & Shen, X. (2024). Evaluating implied urban nature vitality in San Francisco: An interdisciplinary approach combining census data, street view images, and social media analysis. Urban Forestry & Urban Greening, 95, 128289.

TST_SAR.name: Spatial Autoregressive Model
TST_SAR.definition: The Spatial Autoregressive Model is a regression technique designed to handle spatial dependence in geographical data. Unlike standard regression, which assumes independent observations, SAR accounts for the fact that data points in close proximity often influence one another (spatial autocorrelation). By incorporating a spatial weights matrix, the model adjusts for spatial lag (where a neighbor's value affects the focal value) or spatial error. This ensures unbiased parameter estimates in studies involving regional science, urban planning, and environmental modeling.

supporting_papers.citation: An, S., Jang, H., Kim, H., Song, Y., & Ahn, K. (2023). Assessment of street-level greenness and its association with housing prices in a metropolitan area. Scientific Reports, 13(1).

TST_WIL.name: Wilcoxon Rank Sum Test
TST_WIL.definition: A non-parametric statistical hypothesis test used to compare two related samples.

TST_CLU.definition: Statistical methods for grouping a set of objects in such a way that objects in the same group are more similar to each other.

TST_LRT.name: Likelihood Ratio Test
TST_LRT.definition: A statistical test used to compare the goodness of fit of two competing statistical models.

TST_DES.name: Descriptive Statistics
TST_DES.definition: Statistical procedures used to summarize, organize, and describe the characteristics of a data set (e.g., mean, median, standard deviation, frequency) without using probability theory to make inferences or predictions about a larger population.

supporting_papers.citation: Hu, A., Yabuki, N., Fukuda, T., Kaga, H., Takeda, S., & Matsuo, K. (2023). Harnessing multiple data sources and emerging technologies for comprehensive urban green space evaluation. Cities, 143, 104562.

TST_UNSPECIFIED.name: Unspecified Statistical Test
TST_UNSPECIFIED.definition: A designation used in data coding when the specific statistical methodology or test used in a study is not explicitly reported by the authors, or when the description provided does not match standard classification categories. This code ensures that the record is complete even when the precise analytical technique remains ambiguous or undefined in the source material.

supporting_papers.citation: Li, X., Ratti, C., & Seiferling, I. (2017). Mapping Urban Landscapes Along Streets Using Google Street View. Lecture Notes in Geoinformation and Cartography, 341–356.

Li, X., Ratti, C., & Seiferling, I. (2018). Quantifying the shade provision of street trees in urban landscape: A case study in Boston, USA, using Google Street View. Landscape and Urban Planning, 169, 81–91.

TST_SUR.name: Seemingly Unrelated Regressions
TST_SUR.definition: A statistical technique used in econometrics that generalizes a linear regression model. It consists of several regression equations, each having its own dependent variable and potentially different sets of exogenous explanatory variables. The equations are estimated simultaneously to account for correlated errors between the equations, which improves the efficiency of the estimators compared to estimating each equation separately using ordinary least squares (OLS).

supporting_papers.citation: Liu, Y., Xiao, T., Liu, Y., Yao, Y., & Wang, R. (2021). Natural outdoor environments and subjective well-being in Guangzhou, China: Comparing different measures of access. Urban Forestry & Urban Greening, 59, 127027.

TST_MSE.name: Mean Squared Error Analysis
TST_MSE.definition: A statistical metric and method used to assess the quality of an estimator or a predictive model. It measures the average of the squares of the errors—that is, the average squared difference between the estimated values and the actual value. In the context of statistical testing, it is often used to evaluate the goodness-of-fit of regression models or to compare the accuracy of different forecasting methods.

supporting_papers.citation: Cheng, H., Li, Z., Gou, F., Wang, Z., & Zhai, W. (2024). Urban green space, perceived everyday discrimination and mental health among rural-to-urban migrants: A multilevel analysis in Wuhan, China. BMC Public Health, 24(1).

TST_LMM.name: Linear Mixed Models
TST_LMM.definition: A parametric linear model that extends simple linear regression by allowing for both fixed and random effects. These models are particularly useful for analyzing data with hierarchical or clustered structures, such as longitudinal data or repeated measures, where observations are not independent. The random effects account for the correlation within clusters or subjects, providing more accurate estimates of standard errors.

supporting_papers.citation: Chan, T.-C., Lee, P.-H., Lee, Y.-T., & Tang, J.-H. (2024). Exploring the spatial association between the distribution of temperature and urban morphology with green view index. PLOS ONE, 19(5), e0301921.

TST_GAR.name: Generalized Autoregressive Conditional Heteroskedasticity (GARCH)
TST_GAR.definition: A statistical modeling technique used to analyze time-series data where the variance of the error term is not constant (heteroskedasticity) but follows an autoregressive pattern. GARCH models are extensively used in econometrics and finance to estimate volatility, assuming that the variance of the current error term is a function of the actual sizes of the previous time periods' error terms.

supporting_papers.citation: Ye, Y., Zeng, W., Shen, Q., Zhang, X., & Lu, Y. (2019). The visual quality of streets: A human-centred continuous measurement based on machine learning algorithms and street view images. Environment and Planning B: Urban Analytics and City Science, 46(8), 1439–1457.

TST_NA.name: Not Applicable
TST_NA.definition: A coding category indicating that a statistical test was not relevant or required for the specific study or record being indexed. This is commonly used for qualitative research, theoretical papers, literature reviews, or descriptive studies where no inferential statistical testing was performed or where the field requires no such designation.

supporting_papers.citation: Jing, X., Li, Z., Chen, H., & Zhang, C. (2024). "Is What We See Always Real?" A Comparative Study of Two-Dimensional and Three-Dimensional Urban Green Spaces: The Case of Shenzhen's Central District. Forests, 15(6), 983.

Chen, J., Zhou, C., & Li, F. (2020). Quantifying the green view indicator for assessing urban greening quality: An analysis based on Internet-crawling street view data. Ecological Indicators, 113, 106192.

TST_BRT.name: Boosted Regression Trees
TST_BRT.definition: A machine learning technique that combines the strengths of regression trees and boosting algorithms. It iteratively builds a sequence of decision trees, where each new tree focuses on correcting the prediction errors of the previous ones. This method is highly effective for modeling complex non-linear relationships and interactions between variables without requiring transformation, making it a powerful tool for predictive modeling in ecological, spatial, and real estate analysis.

supporting_papers.citation: Xiao, L., Wang, W., Ren, Z., Wei, C., & He, X. (2024). Landscape Patterns of Green Spaces Drive the Availability and Spatial Fairness of Street Greenery in Changchun City, Northeastern China. Forests, 15(7), 1074.

TST_GOL.name: Gray-Level Co-occurrence Linear Model (Texture Analysis)
TST_GOL.definition: A method associated with image texture analysis, likely referring to variations of the Gray-Level Co-occurrence Matrix (GLCM). It involves calculating the statistical distribution of pixel intensity pairs at specified spatial relationships to extract texture features such as contrast, correlation, energy, and homogeneity. This is used to classify land cover or identify materials in remote sensing and computer vision.

TST_GWR.name: Geographically Weighted Regression
TST_GWR.definition: A local spatial statistical technique used to model spatially varying relationships between a dependent variable and independent variables. Unlike global regression models (like OLS) that assume relationships are constant across a study area, GWR generates a separate regression equation for every location in the dataset. This allows the coefficients to vary over space, thereby accounting for spatial non-stationarity and providing insights into how explanatory factors change locally.

supporting_papers.paper_file: Luo P, Yu B, Li P and Liang P (2022)
supporting_papers.citation: Luo, P., Yu, B., Li, P., & Liang, P. (2022). Spatially varying impacts of the built environment on physical activity from a human-scale view: Using street view data. Frontiers in Environmental Science, 10.

TST_MLR.name: Multiple Linear Regression
TST_MLR.definition: MTH_MLR is a statistical technique that models the relationship between a single dependent variable and two or more independent (predictor) variables. It is used to determine how much variance in a dependent variable, such as 'landscape preference,' can be explained by a combination of physical indicators (e.g., openness, greenness, coherence). This method generates an equation that assigns weights to each predictor, allowing researchers to isolate the relative influence of specific design elements while controlling for the confounding effects of others.

supporting_papers.citation: Wu, D., Gong, J., Liang, J., Sun, J., & Zhang, G. (2020). Analyzing the Influence of Urban Street Greening and Street Buildings on Summertime Air Pollution Based on Street View Image Data. ISPRS International Journal of Geo-Information, 9(9), 500.
Xiao, Y., Zhang, Y., Sun, Y., Tao, P., & Kuang, X. (2020). Does Green Space Really Matter for Residents' Obesity? A New Perspective From Baidu Street View. Frontiers in Public Health, 8.

TST_OLS.name: Ordinary Least Squares Regression
TST_OLS.definition: The standard linear modeling technique used to estimate the relationship between a dependent variable and one or more independent variables. It works by minimizing the sum of the squared differences (residuals) between the observed values and the values predicted by the linear function. OLS assumes that the relationship is linear, errors are normally distributed and independent, and variance is constant (homoscedasticity), serving as the baseline for comparing more complex spatial or non-linear models.

supporting_papers.paper_file: Luo P, Yu B, Li P and Liang P (2022)

TST_PLS.name: Partial Least Squares Regression
TST_PLS.definition: A statistical method that combines features of principal component analysis and multiple linear regression. It is particularly useful when predictor variables are highly collinear (correlated) or when the number of predictors exceeds the number of observations. PLS projects the observed variables onto a new subspace (latent variables) that maximizes the covariance between the predictors and the response variable, allowing for robust modeling in high-dimensional data environments.

DES_LON.name: Longitudinal
DES_LON.definition: A research design involving repeated observations of the same variables or subjects over an extended period. By collecting data at multiple time points, longitudinal studies allow researchers to detect developments, changes, and causal relationships that cross-sectional designs cannot capture. This approach is essential for distinguishing between age effects and cohort effects, analyzing trajectories of individual change, and establishing the temporal sequence of events. Common variations include panel studies and cohort studies, which track specific groups to understand dynamic processes.

DES_EXP.name: Experimental
DES_EXP.definition: A rigorous research design characterized by the manipulation of an independent variable to observe its effect on a dependent variable, typically involving random assignment to treatment and control groups. This design is considered the gold standard for establishing causality because it minimizes selection bias and controls for confounding variables. By isolating the experimental condition, researchers can attribute observed differences directly to the intervention. It is widely used in clinical trials, psychology, and behavioral sciences to test specific hypotheses under controlled conditions.

DES_CS.name: Case Study
DES_CS.definition: A qualitative research design that involves an in-depth, detailed examination of a particular case (or cases) within a real-world context. Case studies are used to understand complex issues where the boundaries between the phenomenon and the context may not be clearly evident. They rely on multiple sources of evidence, such as observations, interviews, and documents, to construct a comprehensive understanding.

DES_MET.name: Meta-analysis
DES_MET.definition: A quantitative statistical analysis that combines the results of multiple scientific studies on a specific topic. By pooling data from various independent studies, a meta-analysis increases statistical power and improves the precision of effect size estimates. It aims to resolve discrepancies between studies and identify patterns or relationships that may not be apparent in smaller, individual research projects.

DES_SIM.name: Simulation
DES_SIM.definition: A research design that involves creating a theoretical or computational model to replicate the operation of a real-world process or system over time. Simulation studies allow researchers to experiment with different scenarios, variables, and constraints to predict outcomes or analyze system behavior without the costs, risks, or logistical impossibilities associated with experimenting on the actual physical system.

SPU_IND.name: Individual
SPU_IND.definition: The primary unit of analysis is the single human subject, focusing on personal characteristics, behaviors, perceptions, or physiological responses. In this sampling approach, data is collected directly from distinct persons via surveys, interviews, or observations. This level of granularity allows researchers to account for demographic heterogeneity (such as age, gender, and socioeconomic status) and individual variability. It is the fundamental unit in psychology, epidemiology, and social sciences, enabling the examination of how personal attributes interact with environmental or experimental factors.

SPU_TRJ.name: Trajectory
SPU_TRJ.definition: A sampling unit representing the continuous path or sequence of positions moved by an object or person over time. Trajectory analysis focuses on the geometric and temporal properties of movement, such as speed, direction, duration, and tortuosity. Often derived from GPS or mobile tracking data, this unit allows researchers to study mobility patterns, exposure to environmental factors along a route, and travel behaviors. It shifts the focus from static locations to dynamic movement, capturing the experience of space as it is traversed.

supporting_papers.citation: Zhu, J., Li, B., Ouyang, H., Wang, Y., & Bai, Z. (2024). Understanding Urban Residents' Walking Exercise Preferences: An Empirical Study Using Street View Images and Trajectory Data. Buildings, 14(2), 549.

SPU_SIT.name: Site
SPU_SIT.definition: A site is operationally defined as a 'study area' (e.g., the Jianye District) comprised of discrete 'sampling points.' At each site, data is acquired by processing street view images into panoramic views compatible with human visual perspectives. These sampling points act as the fundamental units for calculating visual indices (like the green view index), which are then aggregated to assess the visual environment of neighborhoods or the city.
