LCZ_3.name: LCZ 3 - Compact Low-rise
LCZ_3.definition: Local Climate Zone 3 features a dense collection of low-rise buildings, typically one to three stories tall. These structures are often attached or separated by very narrow alleys, maximizing building coverage within the lot. The surrounding ground surface is primarily paved with hard materials, offering minimal pervious land cover or vegetation. Due to the high density of small structures and lack of greenery, this zone experiences reduced airflow and significant thermal retention. It is representative of historic city centers, dense residential suburbs, or informal settlements where land use is extremely intensive.
LCZ_3.first_confirmed_by: Hua, J., Cai, M., Shi, Y., Ren, C., Xie, J., Chung, L. C. H., ... & Webster, C. (2022). Investigating pedestrian-level greenery in urban forms in a high-density city for urban planning. Sustainable Cities and Society, 80, 103755.

LCZ_4.name: LCZ 4 - Open High-rise
LCZ_4.definition: Local Climate Zone 4 is characterized by an open arrangement of tall buildings, generally exceeding ten stories. Unlike compact zones, the buildings here are set significantly apart, allowing for ample airflow and sky visibility. The space between the structures is dominated by low plants, scattered trees, or grass, rather than continuous pavement. This configuration typically creates a cooler microclimate compared to compact zones because the vegetation aids in evapotranspiration and the spacing prevents heat trapping, although the tall structures can still influence wind patterns and cast significant shadows.

supporting_papers.citation: Wang, K., Fang, X., Ma, Y., Xue, S., & Yin, S. (2022). Assessing Effects of Urban Greenery on the Regulation Mechanism of Microclimate and Outdoor Thermal Comfort during Winter in China's Cold Region. Land, 11(9), 1442.
Yu, C., & Kwan, M.-P. (2024). Dynamic greenspace exposure, individual mental health status and momentary stress level: A study using multiple greenspace measurements. Health & Place, 86, 103213.

LCZ_4.first_confirmed_by: Hua, J., Cai, M., Shi, Y., Ren, C., Xie, J., Chung, L. C. H., ... & Webster, C. (2022). Investigating pedestrian-level greenery in urban forms in a high-density city for urban planning. Sustainable Cities and Society, 80, 103755.

LCZ_6.name: LCZ 6 - Open Low-rise
LCZ_6.definition: Local Climate Zone 6 consists of a sparse arrangement of low-rise buildings, typically one to three stories in height. The buildings are detached and separated by generous amounts of permeable land cover, such as lawns, gardens, or scattered trees. This zone represents typical suburban residential areas where hardscape is minimal compared to the abundance of low vegetation. The open spacing allows for good ventilation and creates a thermal environment that is generally cooler and more responsive to diurnal temperature cycles than compact urban zones.

supporting_papers.citation: Zhang, X., Lin, E. S., Tan, P. Y., Qi, J., & Waykool, R. (2023). Assessment of visual landscape quality of urban green spaces using image-based metrics derived from perceived sensory dimensions. Environmental Impact Assessment Review, 102, 107200.

LCZ_6.first_confirmed_by: Hua, J., Cai, M., Shi, Y., Ren, C., Xie, J., Chung, L. C. H., ... & Webster, C. (2022). Investigating pedestrian-level greenery in urban forms in a high-density city for urban planning. Sustainable Cities and Society, 80, 103755.

LCZ_A.name: LCZ A - Dense Trees
LCZ_A.definition: Local Climate Zone A describes a natural environment heavily populated with deciduous or coniferous trees. The distinguishing feature is a continuous or near-continuous canopy that significantly obstructs the view of the sky and shades the ground. The surface layer consists of permeable soil, leaf litter, or low herbaceous plants. This zone provides maximum evapotranspirative cooling and shading, maintaining lower surface and air temperatures compared to built environments. It includes forests, dense woodlots, or mature urban parks where the density of trees dominates the land cover.

supporting_papers.citation: Li, C., Du, C., Ge, S., & Tong, T. (2023). An eye-tracking study on visual perception of vegetation permeability in virtual reality forest exposure. Frontiers in Public Health, 11.
Xin, B., Zhu, C., Geng, J., & Liu, Y. (2024). Emotional Perceptions of Thermal Comfort for People Exposed to Green Spaces Characterized Using Streetscapes in Urban Parks. Land, 13(9), 1515.

LCZ_A.first_confirmed_by: Li, C., Du, C., Ge, S., & Tong, T. (2023). An eye-tracking study on visual perception of vegetation permeability in virtual reality forest exposure. Frontiers in Public Health, 11:1089423.

LCZ_B.name: LCZ B - Scattered Trees
LCZ_B.definition: Local Climate Zone B represents a landscape featuring a sparse arrangement of trees set against a background of low plant cover, such as grass or shrubs. The tree canopy is open, allowing sunlight to reach the permeable soil surface freely. This zone is typical of parklands, savannas, or agricultural estates with scattered orchards. While it offers some shading and cooling benefits through evapotranspiration, the thermal regulation is less intense than in dense forests (LCZ A) due to increased solar exposure on the ground surface.
LCZ_B.first_confirmed_by: Song, B. (2023). Comparison of thermal environments and classification of physical environments using fisheye images with object-based classification. Urban Climate, 49, 101510.

LCZ_UNSPECIFIED.name: Unspecified Local Climate Zone
LCZ_UNSPECIFIED.definition: A category used when available land use or morphological data is insufficient to assign a specific Local Climate Zone (LCZ 1-10 or A-G). This designation indicates that properties such as building height, sky view factor, or surface cover fraction could not be determined with enough confidence to meet the Stewart & Oke classification standards.

supporting_papers.citation: Li, X., Ratti, C., & Seiferling, I. (2017). Mapping Urban Landscapes Along Streets Using Google Street View. Lecture Notes in Geoinformation and Cartography, 341–356.

LCZ_URB.name: Urban / Built-up Area
LCZ_URB.definition: A generalized aggregation of Local Climate Zones 1 through 10. This term distinguishes broadly defined 'built' environments—dominated by human-made structures and impervious surfaces—from 'natural' land cover types (LCZ A-G). It is often used in simplified urban heat island studies to contrast city areas against rural surroundings.

supporting_papers.citation: Zhang, Y., Li, S., Dong, R., Deng, H., Fu, X., Wang, C., Yu, T., Jia, T., & Zhao, J. (2021). Quantifying physical and psychological perceptions of urban scenes using deep learning. Land Use Policy, 111, 105762.

While specific statistical definitions vary by country, this group typically encompasses individuals aged 15 to 64 (or 18 to 64). This segment acts as the economic base of a population, distinct from dependent groups such as children and the elderly.

patch_notes: Standardized missing/empty fields across Evidence by ensuring all records share the same top-level and nested keys (without expanding free-form dicts such as indicator.variables).
Filled missing scalar values with project missing-value encodings (e.g., NUM_NA/TXT_NA). For structural fields, used empty containers where appropriate (e.g., indicator.variables={}).
Added is_descriptive_statistic and descriptive_content to all Evidence records (default False / TXT_NA).
Replaced any 'N/A' magnitude values in IOM with NUM_NA and harmonized non-numeric magnitude values to categorical unit UNT_CAT.

Documented controlled values for Evidence.relationship.effect_size.type (r, R2, beta, B) in Appendix:D_effect_size_types and added notes to relevant B_units to prevent ambiguity between R² and signed effect sizes.
Added Context.urban_form.schema_note to document the conceptual separation and coding rule between lcz_type_id (LCZ) and space_type_id (setting).

field_guidelines.Context.urban_form.lcz_type_id: Morphology/land-cover classification at neighborhood scale using Local Climate Zone codes from Appendix.L_lcz.
field_guidelines.Context.urban_form.space_type_id: Functional/setting classification of the studied space using setting codes from Appendix.E_settings.
field_guidelines.Context.urban_form.coding_rule: Treat lcz_type_id and space_type_id as complementary axes; do not infer one from the other unless explicitly stated or justified in applicability.conditions.
field_guidelines.Context.urban_form.schema_note: Embedded per-record in Context.urban_form.schema_note to prevent perceived redundancy.

performance_dimension_merge.note: Evidence.performance.dimension_id values were remapped to a 7-dimension scheme; Appendix.C_performance was consolidated accordingly.

VAR_SHP.definition: The visual appearance of outlines or boundaries that define geometric properties in 2D or 3D space through lines, edges, or surfaces.

VAR_POS.definition: A spatial visual characteristic produced by element configuration, referring to coordinates, orientation, and relational arrangement in three-dimensional space.

VAR_SIZ.definition: The size, dimensions, or scale of spatial elements.

VAR_TEX.definition: A spatial visual characteristic produced by combinations of elements, referring to the interaction effect in which occluding and non-occluding visual elements form recognizable patterns at a micro scale.

VAR_COL.definition: An element’s color attributes, including visual characteristics such as hue, saturation, and brightness.

VAR_NA.definition: Indicates that the spatial variable is not applicable or not reported for this operation encoding.

NUM_NA.name: Numeric Not Reported
NUM_NA.definition: Placeholder indicating that a numeric or numeric-like value is not reported in the source and is intentionally unavailable. Used to standardize missing values across Evidence fields such as relationship.statistical.p_value and relationship.effect_size.ci_lower/ci_upper/threshold.

TXT_NA.name: Text Not Reported
TXT_NA.definition: Placeholder indicating that a text/qualitative field value was not reported or is unavailable. Used for non-ID descriptive fields such as IOM.source_indicator.current_value and IOM.source_indicator.target_value when the source does not specify baseline/target levels.

R2.name: Coefficient of determination (R²)
R2.definition: Proportion of variance explained by a fitted model (e.g., simple linear regression). R² is non-negative and does not carry a direction sign; use direction_id to encode positive/negative trend if needed.

beta.name: Standardized regression coefficient (β)
beta.definition: Standardized regression coefficient (beta) from a regression model. Sign indicates direction of effect on outcome; magnitude comparable across predictors in the same model.

IRR.name: Incidence Rate Ratio (IRR)
IRR.definition: Incidence Rate Ratio (IRR) is the exponentiated coefficient from a count model with a log link (e.g., Poisson or negative binomial regression). It expresses the multiplicative change in the expected incidence/count for a one-unit increase in the predictor (IRR = exp(β)). IRR < 1 indicates a decrease; IRR > 1 indicates an increase.

Coefficient.name: Regression coefficient (generic)
Coefficient.definition: A regression coefficient reported on the model’s coefficient scale (often unstandardized). Interpretation depends on the model link function (e.g., linear model: change in outcome per unit predictor; log-link count model: log change in expected count).

Regression Coefficient.name: Regression coefficient
Regression Coefficient.definition: A coefficient from a regression model (typically unstandardized). The sign indicates direction of association; magnitude depends on scaling and the model/link function.

Unstandardized B.name: Unstandardized regression coefficient (B)
Unstandardized B.definition: Unstandardized regression coefficient (B). In linear models, it represents the expected change in the outcome (in its original units) for a one-unit increase in the predictor, holding other variables constant.

Standardized Coefficient.name: Standardized regression coefficient (β)
Standardized Coefficient.definition: Standardized regression coefficient (β), where variables are standardized (typically mean=0, SD=1) before estimation. It represents the expected change (in SD units) of the outcome for a one-SD increase in the predictor.

Standardized Coefficient (Beta).name: Standardized regression coefficient (β)
Standardized Coefficient (Beta).definition: Standardized regression coefficient (β). Often reported as “Beta” in regression outputs; comparable across predictors within the same model because it is unitless.

beta (total effect).name: Standardized coefficient (β) – total effect
beta (total effect).definition: A standardized regression coefficient (β) representing the “total effect” in mediation/path models (i.e., before decomposing into direct and indirect effects).

Pearson r.name: Pearson correlation coefficient (r)
Pearson r.definition: Pearson correlation coefficient (r) quantifies linear association between two variables. Values range from -1 to 1; the sign indicates direction and the magnitude indicates strength.

Coefficient (ln).name: Log-scale coefficient (ln)
Coefficient (ln).definition: A coefficient reported on the natural-log scale. Common in generalized linear models with a log link (e.g., Poisson/negative binomial), where exp(coefficient) yields a rate ratio such as IRR.

Mediation Proportion.name: Mediation proportion
Mediation Proportion.definition: Proportion of the total effect that is explained by an indirect (mediated) pathway in mediation analysis. Typically reported as a proportion between 0 and 1 (or as a percentage).

TXT_NA.name: Missing / not reported
TXT_NA.definition: Placeholder indicating that the effect size type was not reported or not applicable in the source. Use N_missing_values.TXT_NA for missing textual fields.
